soln_description:
Solution. Consider any function $f$ with the required properties. First, we will show that it is injective. If $f\left(y_{1}\right)=f\left(y_{2}\right)$, then for all natural numbers $x$ we have

$$
y_{1} f(x)=f\left(x f\left(y_{1}\right)\right)=f\left(x f\left(y_{2}\right)\right)=y_{2} f(x) \text {, }
$$

and since $f(x)$ is a natural number, it follows that $y_{1}=y_{2}$, which means that the function $f$ is injective.

By choosing $x=1$ in the given equation, we get $f(f(y))=y f(1)$, which for $y=1$ gives $f(f(1))=f(1)$. Since $f$ is injective, it follows that

$$
f(1)=1
$$

and thus for all natural numbers $y$ we also have

$$
f(f(y))=y
$$

From the above relation, it follows that the range of the function $f$ is the entire set $\mathbb{N}$. Therefore, for any natural number $z$, we can find $y$ such that $y=f(z)$ and simultaneously $f(y)=z$, so according to the relation from the problem, we have

$$
f(x z)=f(x(f(y))=y f(x)=f(z) f(x) .
$$

From this, it is easy to deduce by mathematical induction that for all natural numbers $n$, $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}$ we have

$$
f\left(x_{1} x_{2} \ldots x_{n}\right)=f\left(x_{1}\right) f\left(x_{2}\right) \ldots f\left(x_{n}\right) .
$$

We will show that the image $f(p)$ of any prime number $p$ is also a prime number. Suppose that $f(p)=a b$, where $a, b$ are natural numbers different from one. According to (2) and (3), we have

$$
p=f(f(p))=f(a b)=f(a) f(b) .
$$

Since the function $f$ is injective and $f(1)=1$, it follows that $f(a)>1, f(b)>1$, which contradicts the assumption that $p$ is a prime number.

Since $2007=3^{2} \cdot 223$ is the prime factorization of 2007, we get from (3)

$$
f(2007)=f^{2}(3) f(223),
$$

where both numbers $f(3)$ and $f(223)$ are prime numbers. If $f(3)=2$, then according to (2) we have $f(2)=3$ and the smallest possible value of $f(223)$ is 5, so $f(2007) \geqq 20$. If $f(3)=3$, the smallest possible value of $f(223)$ is 2 and we have $f(2007) \geqq 18$. It is easy to see that for any other choice of values of $f(3)$ and $f(223)$, we have $f(2007) \geqq 18$.

We will show that there exists a function satisfying the problem, for which $f(2007)=18$. Define the function $f$ as follows: For any natural number $x$, which we write as $x=2^{k} 223^{m} q$, where $k$ and $m$ are non-negative integers and $q$ is a natural number coprime with 2 and 223, we define the value of $f(x)$ by the relation

$$
f\left(2^{k} 223^{m} q\right)=2^{m} 223^{k} q .
$$

Then $f(2007)=f\left(223 \cdot 3^{2}\right)=2 \cdot 3^{2}=18$. We will verify that this function $f$ has the required property. Let $x=2^{k_{1}} 223^{m_{1}} q_{1}$ and $y=2^{k_{2}} 223^{m_{2}} q_{2}$ be any natural numbers written in the above form. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x f(y)) & =f\left(2^{k_{1}} 223^{m_{1}} q_{1} f\left(2^{k_{2}} 223^{m_{2}} q_{2}\right)\right)=f\left(2^{k_{1}+m_{2}} 223^{m_{1}+k_{2}} q_{1} q_{2}\right)= \\
& =2^{k_{2}+m_{1}} 223^{m_{2}+k_{1}} q_{1} q_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and simultaneously

$$
y f(x)=2^{k_{2}} 223^{m_{2}} q_{2} f\left(2^{k_{1}} 223^{m_{1}} q_{1}\right)=2^{k_{2}+m_{1}} 223^{m_{2}+k_{1}} q_{1} q_{2} .
$$

The smallest possible value of the number $f(2007)$ is 18.

Note. From the above solution, it follows that any function $f$ that satisfies the given functional equation is determined by some bijection $\varphi$ of the set of prime numbers onto itself, which for each prime number $p$ satisfies the equality $\varphi(\varphi(p))=p$, and is defined by the formula

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(1) & =1 \\
f\left(p_{1}^{k_{1}} p_{2}^{k_{2}} \ldots p_{m}^{k_{m}}\right) & =\varphi\left(p_{1}\right)^{k_{1}} \varphi\left(p_{2}\right)^{k_{2}} \ldots \varphi\left(p_{m}\right)^{k_{m}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $p_{i}$ are distinct prime numbers and $k_{i}$ are non-negative integers. Each bijection $\varphi$ with the above property partitions the set of prime numbers into a union of disjoint one-element and two-element sets such that for each of them of the form $\{p\}$ we have $\varphi(p)=p$ and for each of them of the form $\left\{p_{1}, p_{2}\right\}$ we have $\varphi\left(p_{1}\right)=p_{2}, \varphi\left(p_{2}\right)=p_{1}$. Conversely, any such partition determines a suitable bijection $\varphi$.

soln_description:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(a+b) \mid(b(a+b)-(a b+1)) \\
\Rightarrow(a+b) \mid\left(b^{2}-1\right), \\
(a-b) \mid(b(a-b)-(a b-1)) \\
\Rightarrow(a-b) \mid\left(b^{2}-1\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Notice that, $a>b>1$.
Then $b^{2}-1>0, a-b>0$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\Rightarrow[a+b, a-b] \mid\left(b^{2}-1\right) \\
\Rightarrow[a+b, a-b] \leqslant b^{2}-1 .
\end{array}
$$

Let $d=(a, b)$. Then $d \mid(a+b)$.
Also, $(a+b) \mid(a b+1)$, thus, $d \mid(a b+1)$.
Combining $d \mid a b$, we know
$$
\begin{array}{l} 
d \mid 1 \Rightarrow(a, b)=1 \\
\Rightarrow(a+b, a-b)=(a+b, 2 a) \\
=(a+b, 2 b) \leqslant(2 a, 2 b)=2 \\
\Rightarrow {[a+b, a-b]=\frac{(a+b)(a-b)}{(a+b, a-b)} \geqslant \frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{2} } \\
\Rightarrow b^{2}-1 \geqslant \frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{2} \\
\Rightarrow a^{2} \leqslant 3 b^{2}-2<3 b^{2} \\
\Rightarrow a<\sqrt{3} b .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement: One, (40 points) Given integers $a>b>1$, and satisfying $(a+b)|(a b+1),(a-b)|(a b-1)$. Prove: $a<\sqrt{3} b$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- One, (40 points) Given integers $a>b>1$, and satisfying $(a+b)|(a b+1),(a-b)|(a b-1)$. Prove: $a<\sqrt{3} b$. -/
theorem number_theory_189050 {a b : ‚Ñ§} (ha : 1 < b) (hb : b < a)
    (h1 : (a + b) ‚à£ (a * b + 1)) (h2 : (a - b) ‚à£ (a * b - 1)) :
    a < Real.sqrt 3 * b := by

soln_description:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text { Original } & \Leftrightarrow \frac{a^{2} b^{2}}{a+b}+\frac{b^{2} c^{2}}{b+c}+\frac{c^{2} a^{2}}{c+a} \geqslant a b c\left(\frac{a}{a+b}+\frac{b}{b+c}+\frac{c}{c+a}\right) \\
& \Leftrightarrow \frac{a b}{c(a+b)}+\frac{b c}{a(b+c)}+\frac{a c}{b(c+a)} \geqslant \frac{a}{a+b}+\frac{b}{b+c}+\frac{c}{c+a} \\
& \Leftrightarrow(a b+b c+a c)\left(\frac{1}{a c+b c}+\frac{1}{a b+a c}+\frac{1}{b c+a b}\right) \\
& \geqslant \frac{a c}{a c+b c}+\frac{a b}{a b+a c}+\frac{b c}{b c+a b}+3 .
\end{aligned}$$

Let's perform a substitution. Let
$$\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=a b+a c \\
y=b c+b a \\
z=c a+c b
\end{array},\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a c=\frac{x+z-y}{2} \\
a b=\frac{x+y-z}{2}, \\
b c=\frac{y+z-x}{2}
\end{array} \Rightarrow a b+b c+c a=\frac{x+y+z}{2}\right.\right.$$

Thus,
$$\begin{aligned}
\text { Original } & \Leftrightarrow \frac{1}{2}(x+y+z)\left(\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}\right) \geqslant \frac{x+z-y}{2 z}+\frac{x+y-z}{2 x}+\frac{y+z-x}{2 y}+3 \\
& \Leftrightarrow(x+y+z)\left(\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}\right) \geqslant \frac{x-y}{z}+\frac{y-z}{x}+\frac{z-x}{y}+9 \\
& \Leftrightarrow 3+\frac{y}{x}+\frac{z}{x}+\frac{x}{y}+\frac{z}{y}+\frac{x}{z}+\frac{y}{z} \geqslant \frac{x-y}{z}+\frac{y-z}{x}+\frac{z-x}{y}+9 \\
& \Leftrightarrow \frac{2 y}{z}+\frac{2 z}{x}+\frac{2 x}{y} \geqslant 6 \\
& \Leftrightarrow \frac{y}{z}+\frac{z}{x}+\frac{x}{y} \geqslant 3 .
\end{aligned}$$

By the AM-GM inequality, the conclusion holds.
informal_statement:
Example 23 Given that $a, b, c$ are positive real numbers. Prove:
$$\frac{a^{2} b(b-c)}{a+b}+\frac{b^{2} c(c-a)}{b+c}+\frac{c^{2} a(a-b)}{c+a} \geqslant 0 .$$
informal_proof:
Let the given expression be denoted by $E$:
$$E = \frac{a^2 b(b-c)}{a+b} + \frac{b^2 c(c-a)}{b+c} + \frac{c^2 a(a-b)}{c+a}$$
We are given that $a, b, c$ are positive real numbers. Our goal is to prove that $E \geq 0$.

First, we observe that since $a, b, c > 0$, the sums in the denominators are also positive:
- $a + b > 0$
- $b + c > 0$
- $c + a > 0$

The main strategy is to combine the three terms of $E$ into a single fraction. The common denominator is $D = (a+b)(b+c)(c+a)$. By bringing each term to this common denominator, we can rewrite $E$ as $\frac{N}{D}$, where the numerator $N$ is:
$$N = a^2 b(b-c)(b+c)(c+a) + b^2 c(c-a)(a+b)(c+a) + c^2 a(a-b)(a+b)(b+c)$$
The inequality to prove, $E \geq 0$, is therefore equivalent to proving:
$$\frac{N}{D} \geq 0$$

To prove that a fraction is non-negative, we can show that its numerator is non-negative and its denominator is strictly positive.

1.  **Analyzing the Denominator, D:**
    As established earlier, $a+b$, $b+c$, and $c+a$ are all positive. The denominator $D = (a+b)(b+c)(c+a)$ is a product of three positive numbers, and is therefore itself strictly positive.

2.  **Analyzing the Numerator, N:**
    With $D > 0$, the inequality $\frac{N}{D} \geq 0$ holds if and only if $N \geq 0$. We must prove:
    $$a^2 b(b-c)(b+c)(c+a) + b^2 c(c-a)(a+b)(c+a) + c^2 a(a-b)(a+b)(b+c) \geq 0$$
    This is a non-linear polynomial inequality in $a, b,$ and $c$. While expanding this expression is tedious, it can be algebraically verified that this inequality holds true for all real numbers $a, b, c$. The formal proof uses an automated tactic (`nlinarith`) to perform this verification, which essentially finds a proof by rearranging the polynomial into a form that is manifestly non-negative (such as a sum of squares).

Since the numerator $N$ is non-negative and the denominator $D$ is positive, their quotient $\frac{N}{D}$ is non-negative. This concludes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 23 Given that $a, b, c$ are positive real numbers. Prove:
$$\frac{a^{2} b(b-c)}{a+b}+\frac{b^{2} c(c-a)}{b+c}+\frac{c^{2} a(a-b)}{c+a} \geqslant 0 .$$ -/
theorem inequalities_601814 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    a^2 * b * (b - c) / (a + b) + b^2 * c * (c - a) / (b + c) +
    c^2 * a * (a - b) / (c + a) ‚â• 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_601814 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    a^2 * b * (b - c) / (a + b) + b^2 * c * (c - a) / (b + c) +
    c^2 * a * (a - b) / (c + a) ‚â• 0 := by
  have ha1 : a > 0 := ha
  have hb1 : b > 0 := hb
  have hc1 : c > 0 := hc
  have h1 : a + b > 0 := by positivity
  have h2 : b + c > 0 := by positivity
  have h3 : c + a > 0 := by positivity

  have eq1 : a^2 * b * (b - c) / (a + b) + b^2 * c * (c - a) / (b + c) + c^2 * a * (a - b) / (c + a) =
    (a^2 * b * (b - c) * (b + c) * (c + a) + b^2 * c * (c - a) * (a + b) * (c + a) + c^2 * a * (a - b) * (a + b) * (b + c)) / ((a + b) * (b + c) * (c + a)) := by 
      field_simp
      ring
  rw [eq1]
  apply div_nonneg
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a * b - b * c), sq_nonneg (b * c - c * a), sq_nonneg (c * a - a * b),
          sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (c - a),
          sq_nonneg (a * (a - b)), sq_nonneg (b * (b - c)), sq_nonneg (c * (c - a)),
          mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos hb hc, mul_pos hc ha, 
          mul_pos ha1 (show 0 < a by linarith), 
          mul_pos hb1 (show 0 < b by linarith), 
          mul_pos hc1 (show 0 < c by linarith)]
  positivity

informal_statement: Simplify the following expression: $$\sqrt{\sqrt{4096} + \sqrt[3]{4096} + \sqrt[4]{4096}}$$
informal_proof:
The goal is to prove the identity $\sqrt{\sqrt{4096} + \sqrt[3]{4096} + \sqrt[4]{4096}} = 2\sqrt{22}$.

We will prove this by simplifying the expression on the left-hand side. We evaluate each term under the outermost square root individually.

1.  **Evaluate $\sqrt{4096}$:**
    We claim that $\sqrt{4096} = 64$. By the definition of the square root for real numbers, this is true if and only if $64^2 = 4096$ and $64 \ge 0$. Both conditions are true, as $64 \times 64 = 4096$ and $64$ is non-negative. Thus, we have established that $\sqrt{4096} = 64$.

2.  **Evaluate $\sqrt[3]{4096}$:**
    We claim that $\sqrt[3]{4096} = 16$. To show this, we first express $4096$ as a power of $2$. Since $4096 = 2^{12}$, we can rewrite the expression as $(2^{12})^{1/3}$. Using the power rule $(x^a)^b = x^{ab}$, this becomes $2^{12 \times (1/3)} = 2^4$. Since $2^4 = 16$, we have $\sqrt[3]{4096} = 16$.

3.  **Evaluate $\sqrt[4]{4096}$:**
    Similarly, we claim that $\sqrt[4]{4096} = 8$. Again, we write $4096$ as $2^{12}$. The expression becomes $(2^{12})^{1/4}$. Applying the power rule, we get $2^{12 \times (1/4)} = 2^3$. Since $2^3 = 8$, we have $\sqrt[4]{4096} = 8$.

Now, we substitute these simplified values back into the original equation:
$$ \sqrt{64 + 16 + 8} = 2\sqrt{22} $$
Summing the numbers inside the square root gives:
$$ \sqrt{88} = 2\sqrt{22} $$
To prove this final equality, we can show that the squares of both sides are equal and that the right-hand side is non-negative.

First, the right-hand side, $2\sqrt{22}$, is non-negative because $\sqrt{22} \ge 0$ and $2 > 0$.

Second, we square both sides:
- The square of the left-hand side is $(\sqrt{88})^2 = 88$.
- The square of the right-hand side is $(2\sqrt{22})^2 = 2^2 \times (\sqrt{22})^2 = 4 \times 22 = 88$.

Since both sides are non-negative and their squares are equal, the equality $\sqrt{88} = 2\sqrt{22}$ holds. This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Simplify the following expression: $$\sqrt{\sqrt{4096} + \sqrt[3]{4096} + \sqrt[4]{4096}}$$ -/
theorem algebra_19803 : Real.sqrt (Real.sqrt 4096 + (4096) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) + (4096) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 4)) = 2 * Real.sqrt 22 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_19803 : Real.sqrt (Real.sqrt 4096 + (4096) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) + (4096) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 4)) = 2 * Real.sqrt 22 := by

  have h1 : Real.sqrt 4096 = 64 := by
    rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_mul_self_eq] <;> norm_num

  have h2 : (4096 : ‚Ñù) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) = 16 := by
    have h3 : (4096 : ‚Ñù) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) = ((2 : ‚Ñù) ^ (12 : ‚Ñù)) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) := by norm_num
    rw [h3]
    rw [‚Üê Real.rpow_mul]
    norm_num
    all_goals norm_num

  have h4 : (4096 : ‚Ñù) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 4) = 8 := by
    have h5 : (4096 : ‚Ñù) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 4) = ((2 : ‚Ñù) ^ (12 : ‚Ñù)) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 4) := by norm_num
    rw [h5]
    rw [‚Üê Real.rpow_mul]
    norm_num
    all_goals norm_num

  rw [h1, h2, h4]

  rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_mul_self_eq] <;> norm_num
  <;> ring_nf <;> norm_num [Real.sq_sqrt]
  all_goals norm_num
  all_goals linarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg 22]

soln_description:
To prove that for every positive integer \( n > 12 \) there exists a Pythagorean number between \( n \) and \( 2n \), we will use the properties of Pythagorean triples and their areas.

1. **Understanding Pythagorean Triples**:
   A Pythagorean triple consists of three positive integers \( (a, b, c) \) such that \( a^2 + b^2 = c^2 \). The area \( S \) of the right-angled triangle formed by these sides is given by:
   \[
   S = \frac{1}{2} \times a \times b
   \]
   For simplicity, we will use the formula for generating Pythagorean triples:
   \[
   a = m^2 - n^2, \quad b = 2mn, \quad c = m^2 + n^2
   \]
   where \( m \) and \( n \) are positive integers with \( m > n \).

2. **Calculating the Area**:
   The area \( S \) of the triangle with sides \( a \) and \( b \) is:
   \[
   S = \frac{1}{2} \times (m^2 - n^2) \times (2mn) = mn(m^2 - n^2)
   \]

3. **Choosing Specific Values**:
   Let's choose specific values for \( m \) and \( n \) to generate areas that fit within the desired range \( (n, 2n) \).

   - For \( m = 2 \) and \( n = 1 \):
     \[
     a = 2^2 - 1^2 = 4 - 1 = 3, \quad b = 2 \times 2 \times 1 = 4
     \]
     \[
     S = 2 \times 1 \times (2^2 - 1^2) = 2 \times 1 \times 3 = 6
     \]
     Multiplying by \( c^2 \) where \( c \) is an integer, we get:
     \[
     S = 6c^2
     \]
     For \( c = 1, 2, 3, \ldots \), we get areas \( 6, 24, 54, 96, \ldots \).

   - For \( m = 3 \) and \( n = 2 \):
     \[
     a = 3^2 - 2^2 = 9 - 4 = 5, \quad b = 2 \times 3 \times 2 = 12
     \]
     \[
     S = 3 \times 2 \times (3^2 - 2^2) = 3 \times 2 \times 5 = 30
     \]
     Multiplying by \( c^2 \) where \( c \) is an integer, we get:
     \[
     S = 30c^2
     \]
     For \( c = 1, 2, 3, \ldots \), we get areas \( 30, 120, 270, \ldots \).

4. **Finding a Pythagorean Number in the Range**:
   We need to show that for any \( n > 12 \), there exists a Pythagorean number \( S \) such that \( n < S < 2n \).

   - For \( n = 13 \), we can use \( S = 24 \) (from \( 6c^2 \) with \( c = 2 \)).
   - For \( n = 14 \), we can use \( S = 24 \) (from \( 6c^2 \) with \( c = 2 \)).

informal_statement: An integer which is the area of a right-angled triangle with integer sides is called [i]Pythagorean[/i]. Prove that for every positive integer $n > 12$ there exists a Pythagorean number between $n$ and $2n.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- An integer which is the area of a right-angled triangle with integer sides is called [i]Pythagorean[/i]. Prove that for every positive integer $n > 12$ there exists a Pythagorean number between $n$ and $2n.$ -/
theorem number_theory_32010 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 12) :
    ‚àÉ k, n < k ‚àß k < 2 * n ‚àß ‚àÉ a b c, a^2 + b^2 = c^2 ‚àß k = a * b / 2 := by

informal_statement: There are two classes of primary school students going to the Youth Palace for an activity, and there is only one vehicle to shuttle them. When the first class of students sets off from the school by car, the second class of students start walking; the car drops off the first class of students at some point along the way, immediately returns to pick up the second class of students, and then heads directly to the Youth Palace. The walking speed of the students is 4 kilometers per hour, the speed of the vehicle when carrying passengers is 40 kilometers per hour, and the speed of the empty vehicle is 50 kilometers per hour. Question: If both classes of students arrive at the Youth Palace at the same time, what fraction of the total distance did the first class of students walk?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- There are two classes of primary school students going to the Youth Palace for an activity, and there is only one vehicle to shuttle them. When the first class of students sets off from the school by car, the second class of students start walking; the car drops off the first class of students at some point along the way, immediately returns to pick up the second class of students, and then heads directly to the Youth Palace. The walking speed of the students is 4 kilometers per hour, the speed of the vehicle when carrying passengers is 40 kilometers per hour, and the speed of the empty vehicle is 50 kilometers per hour. Question: If both classes of students arrive at the Youth Palace at the same time, what fraction of the total distance did the first class of students walk? -/
theorem algebra_594 (d t1 t2 : ‚Ñù) (ht1 : t1 > 0) (ht2 : t2 > 0)
    (h : d / t1 = d / t2 + 40 * t1 / 50) (hd : d > 0) :
    t1 / (t1 + t2) = 1 / 7 := by

informal_statement:
Let $m, n, p$ be fixed positive real numbers which satisfy $mnp = 8$. Depending on these constants, find the minimum of $$x^2+y^2+z^2+ mxy + nxz + pyz,$$
where $x, y, z$ are arbitrary positive real numbers satisfying $xyz = 8$. When is the equality attained?
Solve the problem for:
[list=a][*]$m = n = p = 2,$
[*] arbitrary (but fixed) positive real numbers $m, n, p.$[/list]

[i]Stijn Cambie[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $m, n, p$ be fixed positive real numbers which satisfy $mnp = 8$. Depending on these constants, find the minimum of $$x^2+y^2+z^2+ mxy + nxz + pyz,$$
where $x, y, z$ are arbitrary positive real numbers satisfying $xyz = 8$. When is the equality attained?
Solve the problem for:
[list=a][*]$m = n = p = 2,$
[*] arbitrary (but fixed) positive real numbers $m, n, p.$[/list]

[i]Stijn Cambie[/i]
 -/
theorem inequalities_90800 (m n p : ‚Ñù) (hm : 0 < m) (hn : 0 < n) (hp : 0 < p)
    (hmp : m * n * p = 8) :
    IsLeast {t | ‚àÉ x y z : ‚Ñù, 0 < x ‚àß 0 < y ‚àß 0 < z ‚àß x * y * z = 8 ‚àß t = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2 +
      m * x * y + n * x * z + p * y * z} (12 + 4 * (m + n + p)) := by

soln_description:
Answer: 0.26 (exact value: $\frac{7}{27}$).

Note. In variants 7.1 and 7.3, the exact values 0.15625 and 0.4375, respectively, are also counted as correct.
informal_statement: 7.4. Find the minimum value of the expression $\frac{13 x^{2}+24 x y+13 y^{2}+16 x+14 y+68}{\left(9-x^{2}-8 x y-16 y^{2}\right)^{5 / 2}}$. Round the answer to hundredths if necessary.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 7.4. Find the minimum value of the expression $\frac{13 x^{2}+24 x y+13 y^{2}+16 x+14 y+68}{\left(9-x^{2}-8 x y-16 y^{2}\right)^{5 / 2}}$. Round the answer to hundredths if necessary. -/
theorem algebra_205036 :
  IsLeast {z : ‚Ñù | ‚àÉ x y, z = (13*x^2 + 24*x*y + 13*y^2 + 16*x + 14*y + 68) / (9 - x^2 - 8*x*y - 16*y^2) ^ (5/2)} (7/27) := by

soln_description:
First, we notice that the sequence is increasing. Then, for $1 \leqslant k \leqslant n$, we can divide the relation $a_{k}=a_{k-1}+\frac{a_{k-1}^{2}}{n}$ by $a_{k} a_{k-1}$ to obtain:

$$
\frac{1}{a_{k-1}}-\frac{1}{a_{k}}=\frac{a_{k-1}}{n a_{k}}
$$

A telescoping effect then appears, and we can deduce that

$$
\frac{1}{a_{0}}-\frac{1}{a_{n}}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{a_{k-1}}{n a_{k}}
$$

Since the sequence is increasing, $\frac{a_{k-1}}{n a_{k}} \leqslant \frac{1}{n}$, so we deduce that $a_{n} \leqslant 1$.

To better understand the term $\frac{a_{k-1}}{a_{k}}$ in the sum, let's return to the initial relation. For $1 \leqslant k \leqslant n$, divide this relation by $a_{k-1}$ to obtain:

$$
\frac{a_{k}}{a_{k-1}}=1+\frac{a_{k-1}}{n}
$$

Thus, in particular, $\frac{a_{k-1}}{n a_{k}}=\frac{1}{n+a_{k}} \geqslant \frac{1}{n+1}$ since $a_{n} \leqslant 1$ and the sequence is increasing.

We deduce that $\frac{1}{a_{n}} \leqslant 2-\frac{n}{n+1}$, so $a_{n} \geqslant \frac{n+1}{n+2}>\frac{n-1}{n}$, hence the result.
informal_statement:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Consider the sequence $a_{0}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ defined by $a_{0}=\frac{1}{2}$ and by

$$
a_{k}=a_{k-1}+\frac{a_{k-1}^{2}}{n}
$$

for all $1 \leqslant k \leqslant n$. Show that $1-\frac{1}{n}<a_{n}<1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $n$ be a positive integer. Consider the sequence $a_{0}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ defined by $a_{0}=\frac{1}{2}$ and by

$$
a_{k}=a_{k-1}+\frac{a_{k-1}^{2}}{n}
$$

for all $1 \leqslant k \leqslant n$. Show that $1-\frac{1}{n}<a_{n}<1$. -/
theorem algebra_163424 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : 0 < n)
  (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (ha0 : a 0 = 1 / 2)
  (hak : ‚àÄ k ‚àà Finset.Icc 1 n, a k = a (k - 1) + (a (k - 1))^2 / n) :
  1 - 1 / n < a n ‚àß a n < 1 :=

soln_description: 5. $\mathrm{B}$ Hint: $\max \left\{x_{1}+x_{2}, x_{2}+x_{3}, x_{3}+x_{4}, x_{4}+x_{5}\right\} \geqslant \max \left\{x_{1}+x_{2}, x_{3}+x_{4}, x_{4}+x_{3}\right\} \geqslant$ $\frac{1}{3}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{5} x_{i}+x_{4}\right) \geqslant \frac{1}{3}$. Taking $x_{1}=x_{3}=x_{5}=\frac{1}{3}, x_{2}=x_{4}=0$, then $\max \left\{x_{1}+x_{2}, x_{2}+x_{3}, x_{3}+x_{4}, x_{4}+\right.$ $\left.x_{5}\right\}=\frac{1}{3}$, so the answer is B.
informal_statement:
5. Let $x_{i} \in \mathbf{R}, x_{i} \geqslant 0(i=1,2,3,4,5), \sum_{i=1}^{j} x_{i}=1$, then $\max \left\{x_{1}+x_{2}, x_{2}+x_{3}, x_{3}+x_{1}\right.$, $\left.x_{4}+x_{5}\right\}$ has the minimum value equal to
A. $\frac{1}{4}$
B. $\frac{1}{3}$
C. $\frac{1}{6}$
D. $\frac{1}{8}$
informal_proof:
Let $x_0, x_1, x_2, x_3, x_4$ be non-negative real numbers such that their sum is 1. We want to prove that the maximum of the set $\{x_0+x_1, x_1+x_2, x_2+x_0, x_3+x_4\}$ is at least $1/3$. The given conditions are:
1.  $x_i \ge 0$ for $i \in \{0, 1, 2, 3, 4\}$.
2.  $x_0 + x_1 + x_2 + x_3 + x_4 = 1$.

We will proceed by contradiction. Assume the contrary, that is:
$$ \max\{x_0+x_1, x_1+x_2, x_2+x_0, x_3+x_4\} < \frac{1}{3} $$

If the maximum of a set of numbers is strictly less than a value, then every number in that set must also be strictly less than that value. This gives us the following four inequalities:
1.  $x_0 + x_1 < 1/3$
2.  $x_1 + x_2 < 1/3$
3.  $x_2 + x_0 < 1/3$
4.  $x_3 + x_4 < 1/3$

Now, we sum the first three inequalities:
$$ (x_0 + x_1) + (x_1 + x_2) + (x_2 + x_0) < \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{3} $$
By rearranging and combining terms, we get:
$$ 2(x_0 + x_1 + x_2) < 1 $$
Dividing by 2, we find an upper bound for the sum of the first three terms:
$$ x_0 + x_1 + x_2 < \frac{1}{2} \quad (*)$$

From our fourth inequality derived earlier, we have:
$$ x_3 + x_4 < \frac{1}{3} \quad (**) $$

Now, let's consider the total sum, which is given as 1:
$$ 1 = (x_0 + x_1 + x_2) + (x_3 + x_4) $$
Using the bounds we derived in $(*)$ and $(**)$, we can bound the total sum:
$$ (x_0 + x_1 + x_2) + (x_3 + x_4) < \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{3} $$
Calculating the sum on the right-hand side:
$$ \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{3} = \frac{3}{6} + \frac{2}{6} = \frac{5}{6} $$
This implies:
$$ 1 < \frac{5}{6} $$
This is a clear contradiction, as 1 is not less than 5/6.

Since our initial assumption leads to a contradiction, the assumption must be false. Therefore, the original statement must be true. We conclude that:
$$ \max\{x_0+x_1, x_1+x_2, x_2+x_0, x_3+x_4\} \ge \frac{1}{3} $$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 5. Let $x_{i} \in \mathbf{R}, x_{i} \geqslant 0(i=1,2,3,4,5), \sum_{i=1}^{j} x_{i}=1$, then $\max \left\{x_{1}+x_{2}, x_{2}+x_{3}, x_{3}+x_{1}\right.$, $\left.x_{4}+x_{5}\right\}$ has the minimum value equal to
A. $\frac{1}{4}$
B. $\frac{1}{3}$
C. $\frac{1}{6}$
D. $\frac{1}{8}$ -/
theorem algebra_186740 (x : Fin 5 ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (h‚ÇÄ : ‚àÄ i, 0 ‚â§ x i)
  (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àë i, x i = 1) :
  max (max (max (x 0 + x 1) (x 1 + x 2)) (x 2 + x 0)) (x 3 + x 4) ‚â• 1 / 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

theorem algebra_186740 (x : Fin 5 ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (h‚ÇÄ : ‚àÄ i, 0 ‚â§ x i)
  (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àë i, x i = 1) :
  max (max (max (x 0 + x 1) (x 1 + x 2)) (x 2 + x 0)) (x 3 + x 4) ‚â• 1 / 3 := by
  simp [Finset.sum_fin_eq_sum_range, Finset.sum_range_succ] at h‚ÇÅ
  have h3 : x 0 ‚â• 0 := h‚ÇÄ 0
  have h4 : x 1 ‚â• 0 := h‚ÇÄ 1
  have h5 : x 2 ‚â• 0 := h‚ÇÄ 2
  have h6 : x 3 ‚â• 0 := h‚ÇÄ 3
  have h7 : x 4 ‚â• 0 := h‚ÇÄ 4
  by_contra h
  push_neg at h
  -- Now max ... < 1/3 from the previous negation. Let's derive an inequality.
  have h8 : x 0 + x 1 < 1 / 3 := by
    have h21 : max (max (max (x 0 + x 1) (x 1 + x 2)) (x 2 + x 0)) (x 3 + x 4) < 1 / 3 := by linarith
    have h81 : x 0 + x 1 ‚â§ max (max (max (x 0 + x 1) (x 1 + x 2)) (x 2 + x 0)) (x 3 + x 4) := by
      simp
    linarith
  have h9 : x 1 + x 2 < 1 / 3 := by
    have h21 : max (max (max (x 0 + x 1) (x 1 + x 2)) (x 2 + x 0)) (x 3 + x 4) < 1 / 3 := by linarith
    have h82 : x 1 + x 2 ‚â§ max (max (max (x 0 + x 1) (x 1 + x 2)) (x 2 + x 0)) (x 3 + x 4) := by
      simp
    linarith
  have h10 : x 2 + x 0 < 1 / 3 := by
    have h21 : max (max (max (x 0 + x 1) (x 1 + x 2)) (x 2 + x 0)) (x 3 + x 4) < 1 / 3 := by linarith
    have h83 : x 2 + x 0 ‚â§ max (max (max (x 0 + x 1) (x 1 + x 2)) (x 2 + x 0)) (x 3 + x 4) := by
      simp
    linarith
  have h11 : x 3 + x 4 < 1 / 3 := by
    have h21 : max (max (max (x 0 + x 1) (x 1 + x 2)) (x 2 + x 0)) (x 3 + x 4) < 1 / 3 := by linarith
    have h84 : x 3 + x 4 ‚â§ max (max (max (x 0 + x 1) (x 1 + x 2)) (x 2 + x 0)) (x 3 + x 4) := by
      simp
    linarith
  -- Now variables have bound.
  linarith [h‚ÇÅ, h8, h9, h10, h11]

soln_description:
1. **Understanding the Problem:**
   We need to find the maximal length of a non-constant arithmetic progression whose terms do not contain a specific digit \( k \) in their \( p \)-adic representation, where \( p \) is a prime number and \( p \geq 5 \).

2. **Common Difference and Units Digit:**
   Let \( d \) be the common difference of the arithmetic progression. If \( p \mid d \), the units' digit of the terms in the sequence never changes. This is because adding a multiple of \( p \) does not affect the units digit in base \( p \). Therefore, we can consider the sequence with common difference \( \frac{d}{p} \) instead, which still maintains the property of not containing the digit \( k \).

3. **Assumption on \( d \):**
   We can assume \( \gcd(d, p) = 1 \). This is because if \( d \) is not coprime with \( p \), we can reduce the problem to a smaller common difference as explained above.

4. **Invertibility of \( d \) modulo \( p \):**
   Since \( \gcd(d, p) = 1 \), \( d \) is invertible modulo \( p \). Let \( c \) be the modular inverse of \( d \) modulo \( p \), i.e., \( cd \equiv 1 \mod p \).

5. **Form of the Sequence:**
   Consider the arithmetic progression \( dn + e \). We need to ensure that none of the terms in this sequence contain the digit \( k \) in their \( p \)-adic representation.

6. **Modulo Condition:**
   For any term \( dn + e \) in the sequence, we have:
   \[
   dn + e \equiv k \mod p
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   n \equiv c(k - e) \mod p
   \]
   where \( c \) is the inverse of \( d \) modulo \( p \).

7. **Range of \( n \):**
   Since \( n \) ranges over all integers, \( n \equiv c(k - e) \mod p \) will eventually cover all residues modulo \( p \). Therefore, one of the first \( p \) terms of the sequence \( dn + e \) will contain the digit \( k \).

8. **Maximal Length:**
   This shows that the length of the arithmetic progression without the digit \( k \) in their \( p \)-adic representation is at most \( p - 1 \). This length is achieved by the sequence \( 1, 2, \ldots, p - 1 \) itself, as none of these terms contain the digit \( k \) in their \( p \)-adic representation.

9. **Special Cases for \( p = 2 \) and \( p = 3 \):**
   For \( p = 2 \) and \( p = 3 \), the problem is trivial because the \( p \)-adic representation has very limited digits (0 and 1 for \( p = 2 \), and 0, 1, and 2 for \( p = 3 \)). Therefore, the maximal length of the sequence without a specific digit \( k \) is very small and does not provide meaningful insight.

\(\blacksquare\)

The final answer is \( \boxed{ p - 1 } \)
informal_statement: Let $p$ be a prime number, $p \ge 5$, and $k$ be a digit in the $p$-adic representation of positive integers. Find the maximal length of a non constant arithmetic progression whose terms do not contain the digit $k$ in their $p$-adic representation.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $p$ be a prime number, $p \ge 5$, and $k$ be a digit in the $p$-adic representation of positive integers. Find the maximal length of a non constant arithmetic progression whose terms do not contain the digit $k$ in their $p$-adic representation. -/
theorem number_theory_73795 (p k : ‚Ñï) (hp : Nat.Prime p) (hk : k < p) (hpk : p ‚â• 5) :
    IsGreatest {n | ‚àÉ a d : ‚Ñï, a > 0 ‚àß d ‚â† 0 ‚àß ‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range n, ¬¨(k ‚àà Nat.digits p (a + d * i))} (p - 1) := by

soln_description:
Answer: $\alpha=2 \pi n, n \in \mathbb{Z}$ and $\beta=\mp \frac{\pi}{3}+2 \pi l, l \in \mathbb{Z}$.

Solution:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\sin (\alpha-\beta)=\sin \alpha-\sin \beta \\
\cos (\alpha-\beta)=\cos \alpha-\cos \beta
\end{array}\right.
$$

From the first equality, it follows that $2 \sin \left(\frac{\alpha-\beta}{2}\right) \cos \left(\frac{\alpha-\beta}{2}\right)=2 \sin \left(\frac{\alpha-\beta}{2}\right) \cos \left(\frac{\alpha+\beta}{2}\right)$

Hence,

$$
\left[\begin{array} { l } 
{ \operatorname { sin } ( \frac { \alpha - \beta } { 2 } ) = 0 } \\
{ \operatorname { cos } ( \frac { \alpha + \beta } { 2 } ) = \operatorname { cos } ( \frac { \alpha - \beta } { 2 } ) }
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow \left[\begin{array}{l}
\alpha-\beta=2 \pi k, k \in \mathbb{Z} \\
\frac{\alpha+\beta}{2}= \pm \frac{\alpha-\beta}{2}+2 \pi n, n \in \mathbb{Z}
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

In the first case, $\cos \alpha=\cos \beta$. Thus, the "cosine of sum" formula turns into $1=0$, which is impossible.

In the second case, we get either $\beta=2 \pi n, n \in \mathbb{Z}$ or $\alpha=2 \pi n, n \in \mathbb{Z}$. Then the second equality turns into $\cos \alpha=\cos \alpha-1$, which is impossible, or $\cos \beta=1-\cos \beta$, from which $\beta=\mp \frac{\pi}{3}+2 \pi l, l \in \mathbb{Z}$.
informal_statement: 3. (2 points) A poor student wrote the following incorrect formulas for the sine and cosine of the difference: $\sin (\alpha-\beta)=$ $\sin \alpha-\sin \beta$ and $\cos (\alpha-\beta)=\cos \alpha-\cos \beta$. In his defense, he said that for some $\alpha$ and $\beta$ his formulas are still correct. Find all such pairs $(\alpha, \beta)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. (2 points) A poor student wrote the following incorrect formulas for the sine and cosine of the difference: $\sin (\alpha-\beta)=$ $\sin \alpha-\sin \beta$ and $\cos (\alpha-\beta)=\cos \alpha-\cos \beta$. In his defense, he said that for some $\alpha$ and $\beta$ his formulas are still correct. Find all such pairs $(\alpha, \beta)$. -/
theorem algebra_207977 (Œ± Œ≤ : ‚Ñù) :
    (‚àÉ Œ± Œ≤ : ‚Ñù, Œ± = 2 * Real.pi * n ‚àß Œ≤ = 0) ‚Üî
    Real.sin (Œ± - Œ≤) = Real.sin Œ± - Real.sin Œ≤ ‚àß Real.cos (Œ± - Œ≤) = Real.cos Œ± - Real.cos Œ≤ := by

soln_description:
### Part (1)
1. Compute \(a_n\) for \(n = 0, 1, 2, 3\):
   \[
   a_0 = \int_0^t e^{0x} \, dx = \int_0^t 1 \, dx = t
   \]
   \[
   a_1 = \int_0^t e^x \, dx = \left[ e^x \right]_0^t = e^t - 1
   \]
   \[
   a_2 = \int_0^t e^{2x} \, dx = \left[ \frac{1}{2} e^{2x} \right]_0^t = \frac{1}{2} e^{2t} - \frac{1}{2}
   \]
   \[
   a_3 = \int_0^t e^{3x} \, dx = \left[ \frac{1}{3} e^{3x} \right]_0^t = \frac{1}{3} e^{3t} - \frac{1}{3}
   \]

2. Compute \(a_3 - 3a_2 + 3a_1 - a_0\):
   \[
   a_3 - 3a_2 + 3a_1 - a_0 = \left( \frac{1}{3} e^{3t} - \frac{1}{3} \right) - 3 \left( \frac{1}{2} e^{2t} - \frac{1}{2} \right) + 3 (e^t - 1) - t
   \]
   \[
   = \frac{1}{3} e^{3t} - \frac{1}{3} - \frac{3}{2} e^{2t} + \frac{3}{2} + 3e^t - 3 - t
   \]
   \[
   = \frac{1}{3} e^{3t} - \frac{3}{2} e^{2t} + 3e^t - t - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{3}{2} - 3
   \]
   \[
   = \frac{1}{3} e^{3t} - \frac{3}{2} e^{2t} + 3e^t - t - \frac{7}{6}
   \]

3. Show that \(a_3 - 3a_2 + 3a_1 - a_0 \geq 0\):
   - For \(t = 0\):
     \[
     a_3 - 3a_2 + 3a_1 - a_0 = \frac{1}{3} e^{0} - \frac{3}{2} e^{0} + 3e^{0} - 0 - \frac{7}{6} = \frac{1}{3} - \frac{3}{2} + 3 - \frac{7}{6} = 0
     \]
   - For \(t > 0\), since \(e^{3t}\), \(e^{2t}\), and \(e^t\) grow exponentially, the positive terms will dominate, ensuring the expression is non-negative.

Therefore, \(a_3 - 3a_2 + 3a_1 - a_0 \geq 0\).

### Part (2)
1. Compute \(e^t a_0 + (e^t - 1) a_1 - a_2\):
   \[
   e^t a_0 + (e^t - 1) a_1 - a_2 = e^t t + (e^t - 1)(e^t - 1) - \left( \frac{1}{2} e^{2t} - \frac{1}{2} \right)
   \]
   \[
   = e^t t + (e^t - 1)^2 - \frac{1}{2} e^{2t} + \frac{1}{2}
   \]
   \[
   = e^t t + e^{2t} - 2e^t + 1 - \frac{1}{2} e^{2t} + \frac{1}{2}
   \]
   \[
   = e^t t + \frac{1}{2} e^{2t} - 2e^t + 1 + \frac{1}{2}
   \]
   \[
   = e^t t + \frac{1}{2} e^{2t} - 2e^t + \frac{3}{2}
   \]

2. Show that \(e^t a_0 + (e^t - 1) a_1 - a_2 \geq 0\):
   - For \(t = 0\):
     \[
     e^t a_0 + (e^t - 1) a_1 - a_2 = e^0 \cdot 0 + (e^0 - 1)(e^0 - 1) - \left( \frac{1}{2} e^{0} - \frac{1}{2} \right) = 0
     \]
   - For \(t > 0\), consider the function \(f(t) = e^t t + \frac{1}{2} e^{2t} - 2e^t + \frac{3}{2}\):
     \[
     f'(t) = e^t t + e^t + e^{2t} - 2e^t = e^t (t + 1) + e^{2t} - 2e^t
     \]
     \[
     = e^t (t - 1) + e^{2t}
     \]
     Since \(e^t (t - 1) + e^{2t} \geq 0\) for \(t \geq 0\), \(f(t)\) is non-decreasing and \(f(0) = 0\).

Therefore, \(e^t a_0 + (e^t - 1) a_1 - a_2 \geq 0\).

The final answer is \( \boxed{ a_3 - 3a_2 + 3a_1 - a_0 \geq 0 } \) and \(e^t a_0 + (e^t - 1) a_1 - a_2 \geq 0\).
informal_statement:
For $ t\geq 0$, let $ a_n\equal{}\int_0^ t e^{nx}\ dx\ (n\equal{}0,\ 1,\ 2,\ 3)$.

(1) Show that $ a_3\minus{}3a_2\plus{}3a_1\minus{}a_0\geq 0$.

(2) Show that $ e^ta_0\plus{}(e^t\minus{}1)a_1\minus{}a_2\geq 0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- For $ t\geq 0$, let $ a_n\equal{}\int_0^ t e^{nx}\ dx\ (n\equal{}0,\ 1,\ 2,\ 3)$.

(1) Show that $ a_3\minus{}3a_2\plus{}3a_1\minus{}a_0\geq 0$.

(2) Show that $ e^ta_0\plus{}(e^t\minus{}1)a_1\minus{}a_2\geq 0$. -/
theorem calculus_30070 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (ha : ‚àÄ n, a n = ‚à´ x in (0)..t, exp (n * x)) :
    0 ‚â§ t ‚Üí a 3 - 3 * a 2 + 3 * a 1 - a 0 ‚â• 0 ‚àß
    exp t * a 0 + (exp t - 1) * a 1 - a 2 ‚â• 0 := by

informal_statement: Let $x$ and $y$ be positive integers. If $ \frac { 1 } { x } + \frac { 1 } { y } = \frac { 1 } { 2 0 2 3 } $, find the maximum possible value of $x$.
informal_proof:
We want to find the maximum possible value of a positive integer `x` for which there exists a positive integer `y` satisfying the equation `1/x + 1/y = 1/2023`. We will show that this maximum value is 4094552.

To prove that 4094552 is the greatest element of the set of possible values for `x`, we must show two things:
1.  4094552 is itself a possible value for `x`.
2.  Any possible value for `x` is less than or equal to 4094552.

**Part 1: Show that 4094552 is a possible value for `x`**

We need to find a positive integer `y` such that `1/4094552 + 1/y = 1/2023`. Let's choose `y = 2024`. Both `x = 4094552` and `y = 2024` are positive integers. We verify the equation:
`1/2023 - 1/2024 = (2024 - 2023) / (2023 * 2024) = 1 / 4094552`.
Rearranging this gives `1/4094552 + 1/2024 = 1/2023`.
Thus, `x = 4094552` is a valid solution with `y = 2024`.

**Part 2: Show that for any solution `x`, `x ‚â§ 4094552`**

Let `x` be an arbitrary positive integer for which there exists a positive integer `y` satisfying `1/x + 1/y = 1/2023`.

First, we can rearrange the equation. Since `x` and `y` are positive, we can clear the denominators to work with integers. The equation, treated over rational numbers, becomes:
`(x + y) / (xy) = 1 / 2023`
`2023(x + y) = xy`

From the original equation `1/x + 1/y = 1/2023`, since `y > 0`, we have `1/y > 0`. This implies `1/x < 1/2023`, which in turn means `x > 2023`. Similarly, `y > 2023`.

Now, we prove that `x ‚â§ 4094552` by contradiction. Assume that `x > 4094552`.

Let's express `y` in terms of `x` from our rearranged integer equation:
`xy - 2023y = 2023x`
`y(x - 2023) = 2023x`
Since `x > 2023`, `x - 2023` is a positive integer, so we can write:
`y = 2023x / (x - 2023)`

We will now use our assumption `x > 4094552` to constrain the value of `y`. We test if `y < 2024`:
`2023x / (x - 2023) < 2024`
Since `x - 2023 > 0`, we can multiply both sides by `x - 2023`:
`2023x < 2024(x - 2023)`
`2023x < 2024x - 2024 * 2023`
`2024 * 2023 < 2024x - 2023x`
`4094552 < x`

This shows that the inequality `y < 2024` is a direct consequence of our assumption `x > 4094552`.
So, under this assumption, we have established two bounds for `y`:
1.  `y > 2023`
2.  `y < 2024`

This means `y` must be an integer strictly between 2023 and 2024. However, no such integer exists. This is a contradiction.

Therefore, our initial assumption that `x > 4094552` must be false. This forces us to conclude that `x ‚â§ 4094552`.

Since we have shown that `x = 4094552` is a possible value and that any possible value of `x` is no greater than 4094552, we have proven that the maximum possible value of `x` is 4094552.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $x$ and $y$ be positive integers. If $ \frac { 1 } { x } + \frac { 1 } { y } = \frac { 1 } { 2 0 2 3 } $, find the maximum possible value of $x$. -/
theorem number_theory_3822 : IsGreatest {x : ‚Ñï | ‚àÉ y : ‚Ñï, x > 0 ‚àß y > 0 ‚àß (1 / x : ‚Ñö) + 1 / y = 1 / 2023} 4094552 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_3822 : IsGreatest {x : ‚Ñï | ‚àÉ y : ‚Ñï, x > 0 ‚àß y > 0 ‚àß (1 / x : ‚Ñö) + 1 / y = 1 / 2023} 4094552 := by 
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show 4094552 is in the set
    use 2024
    all_goals norm_num
  ¬∑ -- Show that for any x in the set, x ‚â§ 4094552
    intro x hx
    rcases hx with ‚ü®y, hx_pos, hy_pos, heq‚ü©
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    have h_eq1 : (x : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show x > 0 by linarith)
    have h_eq2 : (y : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show y > 0 by linarith)
    have h_eq5 : (x : ‚Ñö) * (y : ‚Ñö) = 2023 * ((x : ‚Ñö) + (y : ‚Ñö)) := by
      have h_eq1 : (x : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show x > 0 by linarith)
      have h_eq2 : (y : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show y > 0 by linarith)
      field_simp at heq ‚ä¢
      linarith
    have h_eq6 : x ‚â§ 4094552 := by
      by_contra h2
      push_neg at h2
      have h2' : x > 2023 := by
        omega
      have h8 : y < x := by
        have h5 : x * y = 2023 * (x + y) := by
          have h_eq1 : (x : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show x > 0 by linarith)
          have h_eq2 : (y : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show y > 0 by linarith)
          have h_eq5 : (x : ‚Ñö) * (y : ‚Ñö) = 2023 * ((x : ‚Ñö) + (y : ‚Ñö)) := by 
            have h_eq1 : (x : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show x > 0 by linarith)
            have h_eq2 : (y : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show y > 0 by linarith)
            field_simp at heq ‚ä¢
            linarith
          exact_mod_cast h_eq5
        have h9 : (2023 : ‚Ñï) * x < x * y := by
          nlinarith
        have h10 : y > 2023 := by
          nlinarith
        nlinarith
      -- magnification
      have h9 : x * y = 2023 * (x + y) := by
        have h_eq1 : (x : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show x > 0 by linarith)
        have h_eq2 : (y : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show y > 0 by linarith)
        have h_eq5 : (x : ‚Ñö) * (y : ‚Ñö) = 2023 * ((x : ‚Ñö) + (y : ‚Ñö)) := by 
          have h_eq1 : (x : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show x > 0 by linarith)
          have h_eq2 : (y : ‚Ñö) > 0 := by exact_mod_cast (show y > 0 by linarith)
          field_simp at heq ‚ä¢
          linarith
        exact_mod_cast h_eq5
      -- exploration
      have h10 : y < x := by
        have h9 : (2023 : ‚Ñï) * x < x * y := by
          nlinarith
        have h10 : y > 2023 := by
          nlinarith
        nlinarith
      -- producing by grid example n project max candidate re reduce reverse stage
      have h11 : y < 2024 := by
        nlinarith [h9, h2']
      -- generating 
      have h12 : x > 0 := by linarith
      -- creating contradiction due to constraints
      have h13 : y > 0 := by linarith
      -- looking for contradiction with all bounds
      interval_cases y <;> omega
    -- generating side upper towards bound
    omega

informal_statement:
6. Given $\cos x+\cos y=\frac{1}{2}, \sin x+\sin y=\frac{1}{3},$ the value of $\cos (x-y)$ is ( ).
A. $-\frac{59}{72}$
B. $-\sqrt{\frac{59}{72}}$
C. $\frac{59}{72}$
D. $\sqrt{\frac{59}{72}}$
informal_proof:
We are given the equations:
1.  $\cos x + \cos y = \frac{1}{2}$
2.  $\sin x + \sin y = \frac{1}{3}$

Our goal is to find the value of $\cos(x - y)$.

First, we recall the angle subtraction identity for cosine:
$$ \cos(x - y) = \cos x \cos y + \sin x \sin y $$
Our strategy will be to find the value of the expression on the right-hand side.

We begin by squaring both sides of the given equations.
From equation (1), we have:
$$ (\cos x + \cos y)^2 = \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2 = \frac{1}{4} $$
Expanding the left side gives:
$$ \cos^2 x + 2 \cos x \cos y + \cos^2 y = \frac{1}{4} \quad (*)$$

From equation (2), we have:
$$ (\sin x + \sin y)^2 = \left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^2 = \frac{1}{9} $$
Expanding the left side gives:
$$ \sin^2 x + 2 \sin x \sin y + \sin^2 y = \frac{1}{9} \quad (**)$$

Next, we add equation $(*)$ and equation $(**)$:
$$ (\cos^2 x + 2 \cos x \cos y + \cos^2 y) + (\sin^2 x + 2 \sin x \sin y + \sin^2 y) = \frac{1}{4} + \frac{1}{9} $$

We rearrange the terms on the left-hand side to group terms involving $x$ and $y$:
$$ (\cos^2 x + \sin^2 x) + (\cos^2 y + \sin^2 y) + 2(\cos x \cos y + \sin x \sin y) = \frac{9}{36} + \frac{4}{36} $$

Using the Pythagorean identity $\cos^2 \theta + \sin^2 \theta = 1$ for both $x$ and $y$, we can simplify the equation:
$$ 1 + 1 + 2(\cos x \cos y + \sin x \sin y) = \frac{13}{36} $$
$$ 2 + 2(\cos x \cos y + \sin x \sin y) = \frac{13}{36} $$

Now, we solve for the expression $\cos x \cos y + \sin x \sin y$:
$$ 2(\cos x \cos y + \sin x \sin y) = \frac{13}{36} - 2 $$
$$ 2(\cos x \cos y + \sin x \sin y) = \frac{13}{36} - \frac{72}{36} = -\frac{59}{36} $$
$$ \cos x \cos y + \sin x \sin y = -\frac{59}{72} $$

Finally, by substituting this result back into the angle subtraction formula, we obtain:
$$ \cos(x - y) = -\frac{59}{72} $$

This concludes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- 6. Given $\cos x+\cos y=\frac{1}{2}, \sin x+\sin y=\frac{1}{3},$ the value of $\cos (x-y)$ is ( ).
A. $-\frac{59}{72}$
B. $-\sqrt{\frac{59}{72}}$
C. $\frac{59}{72}$
D. $\sqrt{\frac{59}{72}}$ -/
theorem algebra_254693 {x y : ‚Ñù} (h‚ÇÄ : cos x + cos y = 1 / 2) (h‚ÇÅ : sin x + sin y = 1 / 3) :
    cos (x - y) = -59 / 72 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

theorem algebra_254693 {x y : ‚Ñù} (h‚ÇÄ : cos x + cos y = 1 / 2) (h‚ÇÅ : sin x + sin y = 1 / 3) :
    cos (x - y) = -59 / 72 := by
  have h2 : cos (x - y) = cos x * cos y + sin x * sin y := by
    rw [cos_sub]

  have h3 : (cos x + cos y) ^ 2 = 1 / 4 := by
    rw [h‚ÇÄ]
    all_goals norm_num

  have h4 : (sin x + sin y) ^ 2 = 1 / 9 := by
    rw [h‚ÇÅ]
    all_goals norm_num

  have h5 : (cos x + cos y) ^ 2 = cos x ^ 2 + 2 * (cos x * cos y) + cos y ^ 2 := by
    ring

  have h6 : (sin x + sin y) ^ 2 = sin x ^ 2 + 2 * (sin x * sin y) + sin y ^ 2 := by
    ring

  rw [h5] at h3
  rw [h6] at h4

  have h7 : cos x ^ 2 + sin x ^ 2 = 1 := by
    exact Real.cos_sq_add_sin_sq x

  have h8 : cos y ^ 2 + sin y ^ 2 = 1 := by
    exact Real.cos_sq_add_sin_sq y

  have h11 : cos x * cos y + sin x * sin y = -59 / 72 := by
    nlinarith [h3, h4, h7, h8]

  rw [h2]
  linarith [h11]

soln_description:
Instruction. Transform each term of the left side of the equation by representing each fraction as a sum of two simpler fractions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{b-c}{(a-b)(a-c)}=\frac{(a-c)+(b-a)}{(a-b)(a-c)}=\frac{1}{a-b}+\frac{1}{c-a} \\
& \frac{c-a}{(b-c)(b-a)}=\frac{(b-a)+(c-b)}{(b-c)(b-a)}=\frac{1}{b-c}+\frac{1}{a-b} \\
& \frac{a-b}{(c-a)(c-b)}=\frac{(c-b)+(a-c)}{(c-a)(c-b)}=\frac{1}{c-a}+\frac{1}{b-c} \\
& \frac{b-c}{(a-b)(a-c)}+\frac{c-a}{(b-c)(b-a)}+\frac{a-b}{(c-a)(c-b)}= \\
&=\frac{2}{a-b}+\frac{2}{c-a}+\frac{2}{b-c}
\end{aligned}
$$

CHAPTER II

## IRRATIONAL NUMBERS. THE FIELD OF REAL NUMBERS

## ¬ß 6. The Concept of an Irrational Number. Operations with Irrational Numbers
informal_statement:
155*. Prove the identity:

\[
\begin{gathered}
\frac{b-c}{(a-b)(a-c)}+\frac{c-a}{(b-c)(b-a)}+\frac{a-b}{(c-a)(c-b)}= \\
=\frac{2}{a-b}+\frac{2}{b-c}+\frac{2}{c-a} \\
(a \neq b, a \neq c, b \neq c)
\end{gathered}
\]
informal_proof:
We are given that `a`, `b`, and `c` are distinct real numbers, which means `a ‚â† b`, `a ‚â† c`, and `b ‚â† c`. Our goal is to prove the given identity.

First, we must ensure that all expressions in the denominators are non-zero, which is a precondition for the fractions to be well-defined. The given hypotheses are sufficient for this:
- From `a ‚â† b`, it follows that `a - b ‚â† 0` and `b - a ‚â† 0`.
- From `a ‚â† c`, it follows that `a - c ‚â† 0` and `c - a ‚â† 0`.
- From `b ‚â† c`, it follows that `b - c ‚â† 0` and `c - b ‚â† 0`.

With all denominators confirmed to be non-zero, we can proceed by clearing the fractions. We multiply both sides of the equation by a common denominator, for instance `(a - b) * (a - c) * (b - c)`, and simplify. Note that terms like `b - a` can be rewritten as `-(a - b)`.

After this simplification, the original equation is transformed into an equivalent polynomial identity. Specifically, the equation becomes:
`(b - c)¬≤ + (a - c)¬≤ + (a - b)¬≤ = 2(a - c)(b - c) + 2(a - b)(a - c) - 2(a - b)(b - c)`

Finally, we verify this polynomial identity by expanding and simplifying both sides.
- Expanding the left-hand side gives:
  `(b¬≤ - 2bc + c¬≤) + (a¬≤ - 2ac + c¬≤) + (a¬≤ - 2ab + b¬≤) = 2a¬≤ + 2b¬≤ + 2c¬≤ - 2ab - 2ac - 2bc`.
- Expanding the right-hand side gives:
  `2(ab - ac - bc + c¬≤) + 2(a¬≤ - ac - ab + bc) - 2(ab - ac - b¬≤ + bc) = 2a¬≤ + 2b¬≤ + 2c¬≤ - 2ab - 2ac - 2bc`.

Since both sides expand to the same expression, the polynomial identity is true. This confirms the truth of the original identity.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 155*. Prove the identity:

\[
\begin{gathered}
\frac{b-c}{(a-b)(a-c)}+\frac{c-a}{(b-c)(b-a)}+\frac{a-b}{(c-a)(c-b)}= \\
=\frac{2}{a-b}+\frac{2}{b-c}+\frac{2}{c-a} \\
(a \neq b, a \neq c, b \neq c)
\end{gathered}
\] -/
theorem algebra_276238 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (h : a ‚â† b ‚àß a ‚â† c ‚àß b ‚â† c) :
    (b - c) / ((a - b) * (a - c)) + (c - a) / ((b - c) * (b - a)) +
    (a - b) / ((c - a) * (c - b)) =
    2 / (a - b) + 2 / (b - c) + 2 / (c - a) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_276238 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (h : a ‚â† b ‚àß a ‚â† c ‚àß b ‚â† c) :
    (b - c) / ((a - b) * (a - c)) + (c - a) / ((b - c) * (b - a)) +
    (a - b) / ((c - a) * (c - b)) =
    2 / (a - b) + 2 / (b - c) + 2 / (c - a) := by
  rcases h with ‚ü®h1, h2, h3‚ü©
  have h4 : a - b ‚â† 0 := by
    intro h'
    apply h1
    linarith
  have h5 : a - c ‚â† 0 := by
    intro h'
    apply h2
    linarith
  have h6 : b - c ‚â† 0 := by
    intro h'
    apply h3
    linarith
  have h7 : b - a ‚â† 0 := by
    intro h'
    apply h1
    linarith
  have h8 : c - a ‚â† 0 := by
    intro h'
    apply h2
    linarith
  have h9 : c - b ‚â† 0 := by
    intro h'
    apply h3
    linarith
  -- now clear denominators
  field_simp [(show a - b ‚â† 0 by exact h4), (show a - c ‚â† 0 by exact h5), (show b - c ‚â† 0 by exact h6), (show b - a ‚â† 0 by exact h7), (show c - a ‚â† 0 by exact h8), (show c - b ‚â† 0 by exact h9)]
  ring

soln_description:
1. Define the function \( f(t) = t^2 - t + 1 \).

2. Suppose \( k \prod (x^2 - x + 1) \ge (xyz)^2 - xyz + 1 \) for all \( x, y, z \in \mathbb{R} \) with \( x \le 0 \). Then for fixed \( y, z \), the quadratic 
   \[
   P_{y,z}(x) = x^2(kf(y)f(z) - y^2z^2) - x(kf(y)f(z) - yz) + (kf(y)f(z) - 1)
   \]
   must be nonnegative for all \( x \le 0 \). 

3. In particular, \( P_{y,z}(0) = kf(y)f(z) - 1 \) and 
   \[
   \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{P_{y,z}(x)}{x^2} = kf(y)f(z) - y^2z^2
   \]
   must be nonnegative for all \( y, z \).

4. Conversely, if \( kf(y)f(z) \ge 1 \) and \( kf(y)f(z) \ge y^2z^2 \) for all \( y, z \), then by the Arithmetic Mean-Geometric Mean Inequality (AM-GM), \( kf(y)f(z) \ge yz \) as well. We trivially have \( P_{y,z}(x) \ge 0 \) for all \( x \le 0 \) (as the \( x^2, -x, 1 \) coefficients are all nonnegative).

5. Thus, the problem reduces to finding the smallest \( k \) always satisfying \( kf(y)f(z) \ge 1 \) and \( kf(y)f(z) \ge y^2z^2 \). As \( f(t) = \left(t - \frac{1}{2}\right)^2 + \frac{3}{4} \), the first inequality holds if \( k \ge \frac{16}{9} \). If \( yz = 0 \), the second trivially holds for \( k \ge 0 \); otherwise, since \( f(t^{-1}) = f(t)t^{-2} \) for all \( t \ne 0 \), it holds for \( k \ge \frac{16}{9} \).

6. We conclude the smallest working value is \( \frac{16}{9} \), with equality at \( (0, \frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}) \) and cyclic shifts.

---

We present another proof of \( \frac{16}{9} f(x)f(y)f(z) \ge f(xyz) \). It suffices to prove the stronger fact that \( \frac{4}{3} f(x)f(y) \ge f(xy) \) whenever \( x, y \) are not both positive. (Without loss of generality, either \( x, y, z \le 0 \), or \( xy \le 0 \); then \( \frac{16}{9} f(x)f(y)f(z) \ge \frac{4}{3} f(xy)f(z) \ge f(xyz) \).)

7. But \( 4f(x)f(y) - 3f(xy) \) is simply
   \[
   [4f(y) - 3y^2]x^2 - [4f(y) - 3y]x + [4f(y) - 3] = (y - 2)^2 x^2 - (4y^2 - 7y + 4)x + (2y - 1)^2.
   \]
   There are many ways to prove this is nonnegative. For instance, without loss of generality, \( y \le 0 \); then it suffices to prove the discriminant
   \[
   (4y^2 - 7y + 4)^2 - 4(y - 2)^2(2y - 1)^2 = (4y^2 - 7y + 4)^2 - (4y^2 - 10y + 4)^2
   \]
   is nonnegative. But \( y \le 0 \) and \( 8y^2 - 17y + 8 \ge 0 \), so we're done.

\(\blacksquare\)

The final answer is \( \boxed{ \frac{16}{9} } \)
informal_statement: Find the least real number $k$ with the following property: if the real numbers $x$, $y$, and $z$ are not all positive, then \[k(x^{2}-x+1)(y^{2}-y+1)(z^{2}-z+1)\geq (xyz)^{2}-xyz+1.\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Find the least real number $k$ with the following property: if the real numbers $x$, $y$, and $z$ are not all positive, then \[k(x^{2}-x+1)(y^{2}-y+1)(z^{2}-z+1)\geq (xyz)^{2}-xyz+1.\] -/
theorem inequalities_49485 {k : ‚Ñù} :
    IsLeast {k | ‚àÄ x y z : ‚Ñù, ¬¨(x > 0 ‚àß y > 0 ‚àß z > 0) ‚Üí k * (x^2 - x + 1) * (y^2 - y + 1) * (z^2 - z + 1) ‚â• (x * y * z)^2 - x * y * z + 1} (16 / 9) := by

informal_statement: 14. In the city of Meow, where mathematics is everywhere, siblings Milli and Geo face a new challenge: they need to select some different odd numbers so that their sum equals 2023. How many odd numbers can they select at most? $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 14. In the city of Meow, where mathematics is everywhere, siblings Milli and Geo face a new challenge: they need to select some different odd numbers so that their sum equals 2023. How many odd numbers can they select at most? $\qquad$ -/
theorem number_theory_271669 (S : Finset ‚Ñï) (hS : ‚àÄ n ‚àà S, Odd n) (hS' : ‚àë n ‚àà S, n = 2023) :
    S.card ‚â§ 43 := by

soln_description:
1. Given the equation:
   \[
   (a+b+c)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right) = \frac{1007}{1008}
   \]
   We can rewrite \(\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c}\) as:
   \[
   \frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} = \frac{ab + bc + ca}{abc}
   \]
   Substituting this into the given equation, we get:
   \[
   (a+b+c) \cdot \frac{ab + bc + ca}{abc} = \frac{1007}{1008}
   \]
   Simplifying, we have:
   \[
   \frac{(a+b+c)(ab+bc+ca)}{abc} = \frac{1007}{1008}
   \]
   Multiplying both sides by \(\frac{abc}{1007}\), we get:
   \[
   (a+b+c)(ab+bc+ca) = \frac{1007}{1008} \cdot abc
   \]

2. We are also given the identity:
   \[
   \frac{ab}{(a+c)(b+c)} + \frac{bc}{(b+a)(c+a)} + \frac{ca}{(c+b)(a+b)} + \frac{2abc}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)} = 1
   \]
   Let \(S = \frac{ab}{(a+c)(b+c)} + \frac{bc}{(b+a)(c+a)} + \frac{ca}{(c+b)(a+b)}\). Then the identity becomes:
   \[
   S + \frac{2abc}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)} = 1
   \]
   Solving for \(S\), we get:
   \[
   S = 1 - \frac{2abc}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}
   \]

3. To find \(S\), we need to evaluate \(\frac{2abc}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}\). From the given condition:
   \[
   (a+b+c)(ab+bc+ca) = \frac{1007}{1008} \cdot abc
   \]
   We can rewrite this as:
   \[
   (a+b+c)(ab+bc+ca) = \frac{1007}{1008} \cdot abc
   \]
   Dividing both sides by \(abc\), we get:
   \[
   \frac{(a+b+c)(ab+bc+ca)}{abc} = \frac{1007}{1008}
   \]
   Simplifying, we have:
   \[
   \frac{a+b+c}{a} + \frac{a+b+c}{b} + \frac{a+b+c}{c} = \frac{1007}{1008}
   \]

4. Now, we need to find the value of \(\frac{2abc}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}\). Given the identity:
   \[
   S + \frac{2abc}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)} = 1
   \]
   We know that:
   \[
   S = 1 - \frac{2abc}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}
   \]
   Substituting the given condition, we get:
   \[
   S = 1 - \frac{2abc}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)}
   \]
   Since \(\frac{2abc}{(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)} = 1 - S\), we have:
   \[
   S = 2017
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{2017}\)
informal_statement:
Let $a$, $b$ and $c$ be real numbers such that $abc(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)\neq0$ and $(a+b+c)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right)=\frac{1007}{1008}$
Prove that $\frac{ab}{(a+c)(b+c)}+\frac{bc}{(b+a)(c+a)}+\frac{ca}{(c+b)(a+b)}=2017$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a$, $b$ and $c$ be real numbers such that $abc(a+b)(b+c)(c+a)\neq0$ and $(a+b+c)\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right)=\frac{1007}{1008}$
Prove that $\frac{ab}{(a+c)(b+c)}+\frac{bc}{(b+a)(c+a)}+\frac{ca}{(c+b)(a+b)}=2017$ -/
theorem algebra_31125 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (h‚ÇÄ : a * b * c * (a + b) * (b + c) * (c + a) ‚â† 0)
    (h‚ÇÅ : (a + b + c) * (1 / a + 1 / b + 1 / c) = 1007 / 1008) :
    a * b / ((a + c) * (b + c)) + b * c / ((b + a) * (c + a)) +
    c * a / ((c + b) * (a + b)) = 2017 := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Domain of definition: $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x+y \geq 0, \\ x-y \geq 0 .\end{array}\right.$

Let $\left\{\begin{array}{l}\sqrt{\frac{x+y}{2}}=u, \\ \sqrt{\frac{x-y}{3}}=v,\end{array}\right.$ where $u \geq 0$ and $v \geq 0$.

In terms of $u$ and $v$, the system becomes $\left\{\begin{array}{l}u+v=14, \\ \frac{u}{2}-\frac{v}{2}=3\end{array} \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}u+v=14, \\ u-v=6,\end{array}\right.\right.$ from which $\left\{\begin{array}{l}u=10, \\ v=4 .\end{array}\right.$ Then $\left\{\begin{array}{l}\sqrt{\frac{x+y}{2}}=10, \\ \sqrt{\frac{x-y}{3}}=4\end{array} \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac{x+y}{2}=100, \\ \frac{x-y}{3}=16\end{array} \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}x+y=200, \\ x-y=48,\end{array}\right.\right.\right.$ from which $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=124 \\ y=76\end{array}\right.$

Answer: (124;76).
informal_statement: 6.118. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}\sqrt{\frac{x+y}{2}}+\sqrt{\frac{x-y}{3}}=14, \\ \sqrt{\frac{x+y}{8}}-\sqrt{\frac{x-y}{12}}=3 .\end{array}\right.$
informal_proof:
We are given a system of equations for real numbers `x` and `y`:
1.  `‚àö((x + y) / 2) + ‚àö((x - y) / 3) = 14` (h5)
2.  `‚àö((x + y) / 8) - ‚àö((x - y) / 12) = 3` (h6)
along with hypotheses ensuring the non-negativity of the terms under the square roots (`h1`, `h2`, `h3`, `h4`).

Our goal is to solve this system for `x` and `y`. We will begin by simplifying the terms in the second equation to express them in terms of `‚àö((x + y) / 2)` and `‚àö((x - y) / 3)`.

First, let's simplify `‚àö((x + y) / 8)`. We can rewrite the argument of the square root as `(x + y) / 8 = ((x + y) / 2) * (1 / 4)`. Using the property `‚àö(a * b) = ‚àöa * ‚àöb` for non-negative numbers, which is applicable here since `(x + y) / 2 ‚â• 0` by hypothesis `h1` and `1/4 ‚â• 0`, we get:
`‚àö((x + y) / 8) = ‚àö(((x + y) / 2) * (1 / 4)) = ‚àö((x + y) / 2) * ‚àö(1 / 4)`.
Since `‚àö(1 / 4) = 1 / 2`, we have established that:
`‚àö((x + y) / 8) = (1 / 2) * ‚àö((x + y) / 2)`.

Next, we simplify `‚àö((x - y) / 12)` in a similar manner. We rewrite the argument as `(x - y) / 12 = ((x - y) / 3) * (1 / 4)`. The property `‚àö(a * b) = ‚àöa * ‚àöb` applies because `(x - y) / 3 ‚â• 0` by hypothesis `h2`. This gives:
`‚àö((x - y) / 12) = ‚àö(((x - y) / 3) * (1 / 4)) = ‚àö((x - y) / 3) * ‚àö(1 / 4)`.
Again, since `‚àö(1 / 4) = 1 / 2`, we have:
`‚àö((x - y) / 12) = (1 / 2) * ‚àö((x - y) / 3)`.

Now, we substitute these simplified expressions back into the second equation (`h6`):
`(1 / 2) * ‚àö((x + y) / 2) - (1 / 2) * ‚àö((x - y) / 3) = 3`.

We now have a system of two linear equations in terms of `‚àö((x + y) / 2)` and `‚àö((x - y) / 3)`:
1. `‚àö((x + y) / 2) + ‚àö((x - y) / 3) = 14`
2. `(1 / 2) * ‚àö((x + y) / 2) - (1 / 2) * ‚àö((x - y) / 3) = 3`

Solving this system (for instance, by multiplying the second equation by 2 to get `‚àö((x + y) / 2) - ‚àö((x - y) / 3) = 6` and then adding it to the first equation), we find:
`‚àö((x + y) / 2) = 10`
and substituting this back gives:
`‚àö((x - y) / 3) = 4`.

To find `x` and `y`, we first eliminate the square roots. From `‚àö((x + y) / 2) = 10`, we square both sides. Since `(x + y) / 2 ‚â• 0` by `h1`, we know that `(‚àö(a))^2 = a`. Thus:
`(x + y) / 2 = 10^2 = 100`,
which implies `x + y = 200`.

Similarly, from `‚àö((x - y) / 3) = 4`, we square both sides. This is valid because `(x - y) / 3 ‚â• 0` by `h2`.
`(x - y) / 3 = 4^2 = 16`,
which implies `x - y = 48`.

We are left with a simple system of linear equations:
1. `x + y = 200`
2. `x - y = 48`

Adding the two equations gives `2x = 248`, so `x = 124`. Substituting `x = 124` into the first equation gives `124 + y = 200`, so `y = 76`.

Therefore, the solution is `x = 124` and `y = 76`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6.118. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}\sqrt{\frac{x+y}{2}}+\sqrt{\frac{x-y}{3}}=14, \\ \sqrt{\frac{x+y}{8}}-\sqrt{\frac{x-y}{12}}=3 .\end{array}\right.$ -/
theorem algebra_187330 {x y : ‚Ñù} (h1 : 0 ‚â§ (x + y) / 2) (h2 : 0 ‚â§ (x - y) / 3)
    (h3 : 0 ‚â§ (x + y) / 8) (h4 : 0 ‚â§ (x - y) / 12) (h5 : Real.sqrt ((x + y) / 2) +
    Real.sqrt ((x - y) / 3) = 14) (h6 : Real.sqrt ((x + y) / 8) - Real.sqrt ((x - y) / 12) = 3) :
    x = 124 ‚àß y = 76 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_187330 {x y : ‚Ñù} (h1 : 0 ‚â§ (x + y) / 2) (h2 : 0 ‚â§ (x - y) / 3)
    (h3 : 0 ‚â§ (x + y) / 8) (h4 : 0 ‚â§ (x - y) / 12) (h5 : Real.sqrt ((x + y) / 2) +
    Real.sqrt ((x - y) / 3) = 14) (h6 : Real.sqrt ((x + y) / 8) - Real.sqrt ((x - y) / 12) = 3) :
    x = 124 ‚àß y = 76 := by
  have ha : Real.sqrt ((x + y) / 8) = (1 / 2) * Real.sqrt ((x + y) / 2) := by
    have h7 : (x + y) / 8 = ((x + y) / 2) * (1 / 4) := by ring_nf
    rw [h7]
    have h8 : 0 ‚â§ (x + y) / 2 := h1
    have h9 : Real.sqrt (((x + y) / 2) * (1 / 4)) = Real.sqrt ((x + y) / 2) * Real.sqrt (1 / 4) := by
      rw [Real.sqrt_mul (by linarith)]
      all_goals norm_num
      all_goals linarith
    have h10 : Real.sqrt (1 / 4 : ‚Ñù) = (1 / 2 : ‚Ñù) := by
      rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
    rw [h9, h10]
    all_goals ring_nf
    all_goals norm_num
    all_goals linarith
  have hb : Real.sqrt ((x - y) / 12) = (1 / 2) * Real.sqrt ((x - y) / 3) := by
    have h9 : (x - y) / 12 = ((x - y) / 3) * (1 / 4) := by ring_nf
    rw [h9]
    have h8 : 0 ‚â§ (x - y) / 3 := h2
    have h9 : Real.sqrt (((x - y) / 3) * (1 / 4)) = Real.sqrt ((x - y) / 3) * Real.sqrt (1 / 4) := by
      rw [Real.sqrt_mul (by linarith)]
      all_goals norm_num
      all_goals linarith
    have h10 : Real.sqrt (1 / 4 : ‚Ñù) = (1 / 2 : ‚Ñù) := by
      rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
    rw [h9, h10]
    all_goals ring_nf
    all_goals norm_num
    all_goals linarith
  rw [ha] at h6
  rw [hb] at h6
  have h8 : Real.sqrt ((x + y) / 2) = 10 := by
    nlinarith
  have h9 : (x + y) / 2 = 100 := by
    calc
      (x + y) / 2 = (Real.sqrt ((x + y) / 2)) ^ 2 := by
        rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
        linarith [h1]
      _ = (10 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2 := by
        rw [h8]
      _ = (100 : ‚Ñù) := by
        norm_num
  have h10 : x + y = 200 := by
    linarith
  have h11 : Real.sqrt ((x - y) / 3) = 4 := by
    nlinarith
  have h12 : (x - y) / 3 = 16 := by
    calc
      (x - y) / 3 = (Real.sqrt ((x - y) / 3)) ^ 2 := by
        rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
        linarith [h2]
      _ = (4 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2 := by
        rw [h11]
      _ = (16 : ‚Ñù) := by
        norm_num
  have h13 : x - y = 48 := by
    linarith
  have hx : x = 124 := by
    linarith [h10, h13]
  have hy : y = 76 := by
    linarith [h10, hx]
  exact ‚ü®hx, hy‚ü©

soln_description:
1. B According to the problem, the 1000 numbers are arranged as follows: $1,1,0,-1,-1,0,1,1,0,-1,-1,0, \cdots$ In other words, they cycle in a pattern of $1,1,0,-1,-1,0$.
Since $1000 \div 6=166 \cdots \cdots 4$, and the sum of the 6 numbers in each cycle is 0, the sum of these 1000 numbers is $1+1+0+(-1)=$ 1. Therefore, the answer is B.
informal_statement:
1. There are 1000 numbers arranged in a row, where among any three consecutive numbers, the middle number equals the sum of the numbers before and after it. If the first number and the second number are both 1, then the sum of these 1000 numbers is
A. 1000
B. 1
C. 0
D. -1
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. There are 1000 numbers arranged in a row, where among any three consecutive numbers, the middle number equals the sum of the numbers before and after it. If the first number and the second number are both 1, then the sum of these 1000 numbers is
A. 1000
B. 1
C. 0
D. -1 -/
theorem algebra_153233 (a : Fin 1000 ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) (h‚ÇÄ : ‚àÄ i, 1 ‚â§ i ‚àß i < 999 ‚Üí a i = a (i - 1) + a (i + 1)) (h‚ÇÅ : a 0 = 1) (h‚ÇÇ : a 1 = 1) :
    ‚àë i, a i = 1 := by

soln_description:
To prove the inequality \( \left| \{\sqrt{m}\} - \frac{1}{2} \right| \geq \frac{1}{8(\sqrt{m}+1)} \) for every positive integer \( m \), we start by defining the fractional part of \( \sqrt{m} \) and using some algebraic manipulations.

1. **Define the integer and fractional parts:**
   Let \( k = \lfloor \sqrt{m} \rfloor \). This means \( k \) is the largest integer not exceeding \( \sqrt{m} \), so we have:
   \[
   k^2 \leq m < (k+1)^2
   \]
   The fractional part of \( \sqrt{m} \) is given by:
   \[
   \{\sqrt{m}\} = \sqrt{m} - k
   \]

2. **Rewrite the inequality:**
   We need to prove:
   \[
   \left| \{\sqrt{m}\} - \frac{1}{2} \right| \geq \frac{1}{8(\sqrt{m}+1)}
   \]
   Substituting \( \{\sqrt{m}\} = \sqrt{m} - k \), the inequality becomes:
   \[
   \left| \sqrt{m} - k - \frac{1}{2} \right| \geq \frac{1}{8(\sqrt{m}+1)}
   \]

3. **Simplify the absolute value expression:**
   Consider the expression inside the absolute value:
   \[
   \left| \sqrt{m} - k - \frac{1}{2} \right|
   \]
   This can be rewritten as:
   \[
   \left| 2\sqrt{m} - 2k - 1 \right| / 2
   \]
   Therefore, the inequality becomes:
   \[
   \frac{\left| 2\sqrt{m} - 2k - 1 \right|}{2} \geq \frac{1}{8(\sqrt{m}+1)}
   \]
   Multiplying both sides by 2, we get:
   \[
   \left| 2\sqrt{m} - 2k - 1 \right| \geq \frac{1}{4(\sqrt{m}+1)}
   \]

4. **Analyze the term \( |4m - (2k+1)^2| \):**
   Note that:
   \[
   4m - (2k+1)^2 = 4m - (4k^2 + 4k + 1) = 4m - 4k^2 - 4k - 1
   \]
   Since \( k^2 \leq m < (k+1)^2 \), we have:
   \[
   4k^2 \leq 4m < 4k^2 + 8k + 4
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   -4k - 1 \leq 4m - (2k+1)^2 < 4k + 3
   \]
   This implies \( |4m - (2k+1)^2| \) is a positive integer.

5. **Case analysis:**
   - If \( |4m - (2k+1)^2| \geq 2 \):
     \[
     \frac{|4m - (2k+1)^2|}{2\sqrt{m} + 2k + 1} \geq \frac{2}{2\sqrt{m} + 2k + 1}
     \]
     Since \( 2\sqrt{m} + 2k + 1 \leq 4\sqrt{m} + 4 \):
     \[
     \frac{2}{2\sqrt{m} + 2k + 1} \geq \frac{2}{4\sqrt{m} + 4} = \frac{1}{2(\sqrt{m} + 1)}
     \]
     This is stronger than the required \( \frac{1}{4(\sqrt{m}+1)} \).

   - If \( |4m - (2k+1)^2| = 1 \):
     \[
     4m - (2k+1)^2 = \pm 1
     \]
     If \( 4m - (2k+1)^2 = -1 \), then:
     \[
     4m = (2k+1)^2 - 1 \implies m = k^2 + k
     \]
     We need to show:
     \[
     \frac{1}{2\sqrt{k^2+k} + 2k + 1} > \frac{1}{4\sqrt{k^2+k} + 1}
     \]
     Simplifying:
     \[
     2\sqrt{k^2+k} > 2k
     \]
     This is clearly true since \( \sqrt{k^2+k} > k \).

Thus, the inequality holds in all cases.

The final answer is \( \boxed{ \left| \{\sqrt{m}\} - \frac{1}{2} \right| \geq \frac{1}{8(\sqrt{m}+1)} } \)
informal_statement:
For every positive integer $m$ prove the inquility
$|\{\sqrt{m}\} - \frac{1}{2}| \geq \frac{1}{8(\sqrt m+1)} $
(The integer part $[x]$ of the number $x$ is the largest integer not exceeding $x$. The fractional part of the number $x$ is a number $\{x\}$ such that $[x]+\{x\}=x$.)

A. Golovanov
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- For every positive integer $m$ prove the inquility
$|\{\sqrt{m}\} - \frac{1}{2}| \geq \frac{1}{8(\sqrt m+1)} $
(The integer part $[x]$ of the number $x$ is the largest integer not exceeding $x$. The fractional part of the number $x$ is a number $\{x\}$ such that $[x]+\{x\}=x$.)

A. Golovanov -/
theorem inequalities_50889 (m : ‚Ñï) (hm : m > 0) :
    |(sqrt m) % 1 - 1 / 2| ‚â• 1 / (8 * (sqrt m + 1)) := by

soln_description:
6. 1996.

From equation (1) we get
$$
\frac{1}{2} b+2 d=1000 d \Rightarrow \frac{b}{d}=1996 \text {. }
$$

By Vieta's formulas we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}=-\frac{b}{a}, x_{1} x_{2} x_{3}=-\frac{d}{a} . \\
\text { Therefore } \frac{1}{x_{1} x_{2}}+\frac{1}{x_{2} x_{3}}+\frac{1}{x_{1} x_{3}}=\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}}{x_{1} x_{2} x_{3}} \\
=\frac{b}{d}=1996
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
6. Given $p(x)=a x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x+d$ is a cubic polynomial, satisfying
$$
p\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)+p\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=1000 p(0) \text {. }
$$

Let $x_{1} „ÄÅ x_{2} „ÄÅ x_{3}$ be the three roots of $p(x)=0$. Then the value of $\frac{1}{x_{1} x_{2}}+\frac{1}{x_{2} x_{3}}+\frac{1}{x_{1} x_{3}}$ is $\qquad$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. Given $p(x)=a x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x+d$ is a cubic polynomial, satisfying
$$
p\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)+p\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)=1000 p(0) \text {. }
$$

Let $x_{1} „ÄÅ x_{2} „ÄÅ x_{3}$ be the three roots of $p(x)=0$. Then the value of $\frac{1}{x_{1} x_{2}}+\frac{1}{x_{2} x_{3}}+\frac{1}{x_{1} x_{3}}$ is $\qquad$ . -/
theorem algebra_316787 {a b c d : ‚Ñù} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : a * (1 / 2) ^ 3 + b * (1 / 2) ^ 2 + c * (1 / 2) + d + a * (-1 / 2) ^ 3 + b * (-1 / 2) ^ 2 + c * (-1 / 2) + d = 1000 * (d)) (x‚ÇÅ x‚ÇÇ x‚ÇÉ : ‚Ñù) (hx‚ÇÅ : a * x‚ÇÅ ^ 3 + b * x‚ÇÅ ^ 2 + c * x‚ÇÅ + d = 0) (hx‚ÇÇ : a * x‚ÇÇ ^ 3 + b * x‚ÇÇ ^ 2 + c * x‚ÇÇ + d = 0) (hx‚ÇÉ : a * x‚ÇÉ ^ 3 + b * x‚ÇÉ ^ 2 + c * x‚ÇÉ + d = 0) :
    1 / (x‚ÇÅ * x‚ÇÇ) + 1 / (x‚ÇÇ * x‚ÇÉ) + 1 / (x‚ÇÅ * x‚ÇÉ) = 1996 := by

soln_description:
1. **Express each term in the series**:
   Each term in the series can be written in the form \(2 \cdot 10^k + 2\), where \(k\) is the number of zeros between the two 2's. For example:
   - The first term is \(2\).
   - The second term is \(22 = 2 \cdot 10^1 + 2\).
   - The third term is \(202 = 2 \cdot 10^2 + 2\).
   - The fourth term is \(2002 = 2 \cdot 10^3 + 2\).
   - And so on, up to the 20th term, which is \(2 \cdot 10^{19} + 2\).

2. **Sum the series**:
   We need to sum all these terms:
   \[
   N = 2 + (2 \cdot 10^1 + 2) + (2 \cdot 10^2 + 2) + \cdots + (2 \cdot 10^{19} + 2)
   \]
   This can be rewritten as:
   \[
   N = 2 + 2 + 2 + \cdots + 2 + 2 \cdot (10^1 + 10^2 + 10^3 + \cdots + 10^{19})
   \]
   Notice that there are 20 terms of 2, so:
   \[
   N = 20 \cdot 2 + 2 \cdot (10^1 + 10^2 + 10^3 + \cdots + 10^{19})
   \]
   Simplifying the first part:
   \[
   20 \cdot 2 = 40
   \]

3. **Sum the geometric series**:
   The sum of the geometric series \(10^1 + 10^2 + 10^3 + \cdots + 10^{19}\) can be calculated using the formula for the sum of a geometric series:
   \[
   S = a \frac{r^n - 1}{r - 1}
   \]
   where \(a = 10\), \(r = 10\), and \(n = 19\):
   \[
   S = 10 \frac{10^{19} - 1}{10 - 1} = 10 \frac{10^{19} - 1}{9}
   \]

4. **Combine the sums**:
   Now, we combine the sums:
   \[
   N = 40 + 2 \cdot \left(10 \frac{10^{19} - 1}{9}\right)
   \]
   Simplifying inside the parentheses:
   \[
   2 \cdot \left(10 \frac{10^{19} - 1}{9}\right) = \frac{20 (10^{19} - 1)}{9}
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   N = 40 + \frac{20 (10^{19} - 1)}{9}
   \]

5. **Sum of the digits**:
   To find the sum of the digits of \(N\), we need to consider the structure of \(N\). The number \(N\) is composed of a series of 2's and 0's. Specifically, it will have 20 digits of 2 and 19 digits of 0. Therefore, the sum of the digits is:
   \[
   20 \cdot 2 = 40
   \]
   Plus the initial 2 from the first term:
   \[
   40 + 2 = 42
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{42}\)
informal_statement:
A number $N$ is defined as follows: 
\[N=2+22+202+2002+20002+\cdots+2\overbrace{00\ldots000}^{19~0\text{'s}}2\] 
When the value of $N$ is simplified, what is the sum of its digits?

$\textbf{(A) }42\qquad\textbf{(B) }44\qquad\textbf{(C) }46\qquad\textbf{(D) }50\qquad\textbf{(E) }52$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def N : ‚Ñï := ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range 19, (2 * 10 ^ (i + 1) - 1) / 9

/- A number $N$ is defined as follows: 
\[N=2+22+202+2002+20002+\cdots+2\overbrace{00\ldots000}^{19~0\text{'s}}2\] 
When the value of $N$ is simplified, what is the sum of its digits?

$\textbf{(A) }42\qquad\textbf{(B) }44\qquad\textbf{(C) }46\qquad\textbf{(D) }50\qquad\textbf{(E) }52$ -/
theorem number_theory_36887 : (Nat.digits 10 N).sum = 42 := by

soln_description: Answer: $\eta_{2}=\frac{\alpha}{100-(100-\alpha) \eta_{0}} ;$ for all.
informal_statement:
3. The heat engine "Lomonosov" 12341 receives heat on the segment $1-2$ and gives it off on the segment $3-4$. Therefore,

$$
\eta_{0}=1-\frac{Q_{34}}{Q_{12}}
$$

(here and below, all heats are assumed to be positive). The engine "Avogadro" 1231 also receives heat on 12, but gives it off on 31, so

$$
\eta_{1}=1-\frac{Q_{13}}{Q_{12}}
$$

The engine "Boltzmann" 1341 receives heat on 13 and gives it off on 34, hence

$$
\eta_{2}=1-\frac{Q_{34}}{Q_{13}}
$$

Combining the three equations above, we get

$$
\eta_{2}=\frac{\eta_{0}-\eta_{1}}{1-\eta_{1}}
$$

$\eta_{1}<\eta_{0}$, because the engine 1231 performs less work with the same amount of heat received, and $\eta_{2}<\eta_{0}$ for all values of $\eta_{0}, \eta_{1}<1$, i.e., for all permissible values. Given that $\eta_{1}=(1-0.01 \alpha) \eta_{0}$, we obtain the answer:
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. The heat engine "Lomonosov" 12341 receives heat on the segment $1-2$ and gives it off on the segment $3-4$. Therefore,

$$
\eta_{0}=1-\frac{Q_{34}}{Q_{12}}
$$

(here and below, all heats are assumed to be positive). The engine "Avogadro" 1231 also receives heat on 12, but gives it off on 31, so

$$
\eta_{1}=1-\frac{Q_{13}}{Q_{12}}
$$

The engine "Boltzmann" 1341 receives heat on 13 and gives it off on 34, hence

$$
\eta_{2}=1-\frac{Q_{34}}{Q_{13}}
$$

Combining the three equations above, we get

$$
\eta_{2}=\frac{\eta_{0}-\eta_{1}}{1-\eta_{1}}
$$

$\eta_{1}<\eta_{0}$, because the engine 1231 performs less work with the same amount of heat received, and $\eta_{2}<\eta_{0}$ for all values of $\eta_{0}, \eta_{1}<1$, i.e., for all permissible values. Given that $\eta_{1}=(1-0.01 \alpha) \eta_{0}$, we obtain the answer: -/
theorem algebra_279418 {Œ± : ‚Ñù} (hŒ± : Œ± > 0) (h : Œ± < 100) :
    (1 - 0.01 * Œ±) * (1 - (1 - 0.01 * Œ±) * (1 - Œ± / 100)) =
    Œ± / (100 - (100 - Œ±) * (1 - Œ± / 100)) := by

soln_description: We have A 2n+1 + B 2n+1 = (A + B)(A 2n - A 2n-1 B + A 2n B 2 - ... + B 2n ). Hence (5 4 + 3 2 ) divides 5 8n+4 + 3 4n+2 . Also one of n-1, n, n+1 must be a multiple of 3, and at least one must be even. Hence 6¬∑(625+9) =3804 always divides (n 3 - n)(5 8n+4 + 3 4n+2 ). 1st Mexican 1987 ¬© John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 21 February 2004 Last corrected/updated 21 Feb 04
informal_statement: 1st Mexico 1987 Problem B2 Prove that (n 3 - n)(5 8n+4 + 3 4n+2 ) is a multiple of 3804 for all positive integers n.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1st Mexico 1987 Problem B2 Prove that (n 3 - n)(5 8n+4 + 3 4n+2 ) is a multiple of 3804 for all positive integers n. -/
theorem number_theory_122077 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 0) :
    3804 ‚à£ (n^3 - n) * (5^(8 * n + 4) + 3^(4 * n + 2)) := by

soln_description:
Solution. The inequality is equivalent to
$$\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\ln a_{i}-\ln \left(1-a_{i}\right)\right) \geq n \ln \left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)-n \ln \left(n-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)$$

Notice that the function $f(x)=\ln x-\ln (1-x)$, has the second derivative
$$f^{\prime \prime}(x)=\frac{-1}{x^{2}}+\frac{1}{(1-x)^{2}} \geq 0(x \in(1 / 2,1])$$

Therefore $f$ is a convex function. By Jensen's inequality, we have the desired result.
informal_statement:
Example 4.1.2. Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers lying in $(1 / 2,1]$. Prove that
$$\frac{a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}}{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\ldots+a_{n}\right)^{n}} \geq \frac{\left(1-a_{1}\right)\left(1-a_{2}\right) \ldots\left(1-a_{n}\right)}{\left(n-a_{1}-a_{2}-\ldots-a_{n}\right)^{n}}$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 4.1.2. Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be real numbers lying in $(1 / 2,1]$. Prove that
$$\frac{a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}}{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\ldots+a_{n}\right)^{n}} \geq \frac{\left(1-a_{1}\right)\left(1-a_{2}\right) \ldots\left(1-a_{n}\right)}{\left(n-a_{1}-a_{2}-\ldots-a_{n}\right)^{n}}$$ -/
theorem inequalities_598774 (n : ‚Ñï) (a : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (ha : ‚àÄ i, a i ‚àà Set.Ioc (1 / 2) 1) :
    (‚àè i, a i) / (‚àë i, a i) ^ n ‚â• (‚àè i, (1 - a i)) / (‚àë i, (1 - a i)) ^ n := by

soln_description:
Solve $17=2^{4}+1$, written in binary as $(10001)_{2}$, it contains only two digits 1. Consider its multiple $17 m$, if written in binary it contains three digits 1, then $m$ written in binary must contain at least two digits 1. Therefore, we can set
$$
17 m=\left(2^{4}+1\right)\left(2^{n}+\cdots+1\right) \cdot 2^{p},
$$

where $n$ is a positive integer, and $p$ is a positive integer or zero. The above expression can also be rearranged into the sum of different powers of 2, and the number of terms is the number of digits 1 in the corresponding binary number. Since the factor $2^{p}$ does not affect the number of terms in the expanded form, we only need to consider $\left(2^{4}+1\right)\left(2^{n}+\cdots+1\right)=2^{4+n}+\cdots+2^{4}+2^{n}+\cdots+1$. According to the problem, this expression can be written as the sum of three different powers of 2 (including $2^{0}=1$). It is evident that $n$ cannot be less than 4, otherwise, there would be at least four terms in the above expression that cannot be combined, contradicting the problem's condition. When $n \geqslant 4$, $2^{4+n} \geqslant 2^{8}$, the corresponding binary number of the above expression is at least a nine-digit number. If it contains exactly three digits 1, there must be at least six digits 0. Such a multiple of 17 definitely exists, for example, $17^{2}=\left(2^{4}+1\right)^{2}=2^{8}+2^{5}+1$.

If a binary number contains exactly three digits 1 and seven digits 0, then it is a ten-digit number; if it is an odd number, it can be represented as $2^{9}+2^{n}+1$, where $n$ is a positive integer less than 9. However, it is not difficult to verify that when $n=1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8$, $2^{9}+2^{n}+1$ is not a multiple of 17. Therefore, such a multiple of 17 can only be an even number, for example, $2\left(2^{8}+2^{5}+1\right)=2^{9}+2^{6}+2$.
informal_statement: Example 10 (1982 British Mathematical Olympiad) A multiple of 17, when written in binary, contains exactly three 1's. Prove that it must contain at least six 0's, and if it contains exactly seven 0's, then it is even.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 10 (1982 British Mathematical Olympiad) A multiple of 17, when written in binary, contains exactly three 1's. Prove that it must contain at least six 0's, and if it contains exactly seven 0's, then it is even. -/
theorem number_theory_175226 (n : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : 17 ‚à£ n) (h‚ÇÅ : {i | (Nat.digits 2 n).get i = 1}.encard = 3) :
    {i | (Nat.digits 2 n).get i = 0}.ncard ‚â• 6 ‚àß
    ({i | (Nat.digits 2 n).get i = 0}.ncard = 7 ‚Üí Even n) := by

soln_description:
Solution 1. We claim that the only solutions are $f(x)=x$ and $f(x)=-x$; it is easy to verify that these are indeed solutions.

Now suppose $f$ satisfies the given equation. Studying $(x, 0)$ and $(-x, 0)$ leads to

$$
x f(0)+f\left(x^{2}\right)=f\left(x^{2}+f(0)\right)=-x f(0)+f\left(x^{2}\right)
$$

and so $f(0)=0$. Then, studying $(0, y)$ and $(-y, y)$ leads to

$$
y^{2}=f\left(f\left(y^{2}\right)\right)=-y f(y)+y^{2}+f\left(y^{2}\right)
$$

and therefore

$$
f\left(y^{2}\right)=y f(y)
$$

Given $(x, y)$, take $z=-(x+y)$, so that $x^{2}+x y=z^{2}+z y$. Then $f\left(x^{2}+x y+f\left(y^{2}\right)\right)=$ $f\left(z^{2}+z y+f\left(y^{2}\right)\right)$, hence from the original equation,

$$
\begin{aligned}
x f(y)+y^{2}+f\left(x^{2}\right) & =z f(y)+y^{2}+f\left(z^{2}\right) \\
x f(y)-z f(y) & =f\left(z^{2}\right)-f\left(x^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Eliminating $z$ and using (1),

$$
2 x f(y)=f\left(z^{2}\right)-f\left(x^{2}\right)-y f(y)=f\left((x+y)^{2}\right)-f\left(x^{2}\right)-f\left(y^{2}\right)
$$

But the RHS of (2) is symmetric in $x, y$ and so $x f(y)=y f(x)$. In particular $f(x)=x f(1)$. Writing $c=f(1)$, and substituting back into the original equation, all the terms cancel except $c^{2} y^{2} \equiv y^{2}$, hence $c= \pm 1$, so $f(x)=x$ and $f(x)=-x$ are the only solutions.
informal_statement:
A1. Determine all functions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ satisfying

$$
f\left(x^{2}+x y+f\left(y^{2}\right)\right)=x f(y)+y^{2}+f\left(x^{2}\right)
$$

for all real numbers $x$ and $y$.

## United Kingdom, Joe Benton
