When they meet for the first time, Alice has completed exactly 30 laps. Determine all possible values of $t$.

Solution: The answer is $t=59$ or $t=61$.

Since Alice ran exactly 30 laps, Bob meets Alice at where Alice started. Since Bob started diametrically across from Alice, Bob ran $n+\frac{1}{2}$ laps for some positive integer $n$. Since Alice and Bob meet only the first time they meet, the number of laps that Alice ran and the number of laps Bob ran cannot differ by more than 1. Therefore, Bob ran either 29.5 laps or 30.5 laps.

Note that Alice and Bob ran for the same amount of time and the number of seconds each person ran is the number of laps he/she ran times the number of seconds it takes he/she to complete a lap.

If Bob ran 29.5 laps, then $30 t=29.5 \times 60$. Hence, $t=29.5 \times 2=59$.

If Bob ran 30.5 laps, then similarly, $30 t=30.5 \times 60$. Hence, $t=30.5 \times 2=61$.

Therefore, $t=59$ or $t=61$.
informal_statement: B1 Alice and Bob run in the clockwise direction around a circular track, each running at a constant speed. Alice can complete a lap in $t$ seconds, and Bob can complete a lap in 60 seconds. They start at diametrically-opposite points.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- B1 Alice and Bob run in the clockwise direction around a circular track, each running at a constant speed. Alice can complete a lap in $t$ seconds, and Bob can complete a lap in 60 seconds. They start at diametrically-opposite points. -/
theorem algebra_290436 (t : ‚Ñù) (ht : t > 0) :
    (t = 59 ‚à® t = 61) := by

soln_description:
Proof 1: From $abc=1$, we get $\frac{1}{a^{3}(b+c)}=\frac{b^{2} c^{2}}{a b+a c}$. Thus, the original inequality is equivalent to
$$
\frac{b^{2} c^{2}}{a b+a c}+\frac{c^{2} a^{2}}{b c+b a}+\frac{a^{2} b^{2}}{c a+a b} \geqslant \frac{3}{2} \text {. }
$$

Using the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(a b+b c+c a)^{2}=\left(\frac{a b}{\sqrt{c a+c b}} \cdot \sqrt{c a+c b}+\frac{b c}{\sqrt{a b+a c}} \times \sqrt{a b+a c}\right. \\
\left.+\frac{c a}{\sqrt{a b+b c}} \cdot \sqrt{a b+b c}\right) \\
\leqslant\left(\frac{a^{2} b^{2}}{c a+c b}+\frac{b^{2} c^{2}}{c a+a b}+\frac{c^{2} a^{2}}{c b+a b}\right)(c a+c b+a b+a c+a b+b c) .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $\frac{b^{2} c^{2}}{c a+a b}+\frac{c^{2} a^{2}}{c b+a b}+\frac{a^{2} b^{2}}{c a+c b} \geqslant \frac{1}{2}(a b+b c+a c)$
$$
\geqslant \frac{1}{2} \cdot 3 \sqrt[3]{a b b c c a}=\frac{3}{2} .
$$

Proof 2: Using the AM-GM inequality.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Since } \frac{b^{2} c^{2}}{a b+a c}+\frac{a b+a c}{4} \geqslant 2 \sqrt{\frac{b^{2} c^{2}}{a b+a c} \cdot \frac{a b+a c}{4}}=b c, \\
\frac{c^{2} a^{2}}{a b+b c}+\frac{a b+b c}{4} \geqslant a c, \\
\frac{a^{2} b^{2}}{b c+a c}+\frac{b c+a c}{4} \geqslant a b,
\end{array}
$$

Thus, adding the three inequalities, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{c^{2} b^{2}}{a b+a c}+\frac{c^{2} a^{2}}{a b+b c}+\frac{a^{2} b^{2}}{b c+a c} \geqslant \frac{1}{2}(a b+a c+b c) \\
\geqslant \frac{1}{2} \cdot 3 \sqrt[3]{a b a c b c}=\frac{3}{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Proof 3: Incremental substitution.
Let $2 a^{-1}=b^{-1}+c^{-1}+\alpha, 2 b^{-1}=a^{-1}+c^{-1}+\beta, 2 c^{-1}=a^{-1}+b^{-1}+$ $\gamma$, then $\alpha+\beta+\gamma=0$, thus
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{4 a b c}{a^{3}(b+c)}+\frac{4 a b c}{b^{3}(c+a)}+\frac{4 a b c}{c^{3}(a+b)} \\
= & \frac{\left(b^{-1}+c^{-1}+\alpha\right)^{2}}{b^{-1}+c^{-1}}+\frac{\left(c^{-1}+a^{-1}+\beta\right)^{2}}{c^{-1}+a^{-1}}+\frac{\left(a^{-1}+b^{-1}+\gamma\right)^{2}}{a^{-1}+b^{-1}} \\
= & 2\left(a^{-1}+b^{-1}+c^{-1}\right)+2(\alpha+\beta+\gamma)+\left(b^{-1}+c^{-1}\right)^{-1} \gamma^{2}+\left(c^{-1}+\right. \\
& \left.a^{-1}\right)^{-1} \beta^{2}+\left(a^{-1}+b^{-1}\right)^{-1} \gamma^{2} \\
\geqslant & 2\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right) \geqslant 2 \cdot 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{1}{a b c}}=6, \text { i.e., the original inequality holds. }
\end{aligned}
$$
$\geqslant 2\left(\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}\right) \geqslant 2 \cdot 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{1}{a b c}}=6$, i.e., the original inequality holds.
Proof 4: $S=\frac{(a b c)^{2}}{a^{3}(b+c)}+\frac{(a b c)^{2}}{b^{3}(c+a)}+\frac{(a b c)^{2}}{c^{3}(a+b)}$
$$
=\frac{b c}{a(b+c)} \cdot b c+\frac{a c}{b(c+a)} \cdot a c+\frac{a b}{c(a+b)} \cdot a b .
$$

Assume $a \leqslant b \leqslant c$, then $a b \leqslant a c \leqslant b c, a b+a c \leqslant a b+b c \leqslant a c+b c$. Thus, $\frac{b c}{a(b+c)} \geqslant \frac{a c}{b(a+c)} \geqslant \frac{a b}{c(a+b)}$, which implies that $S$ is a sorted sum. By the rearrangement inequality, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
S \geqslant \frac{b c}{a(b+c)} \cdot a c+\frac{a c}{b(a+c)} \cdot a b+\frac{a b}{c(a+b)} \cdot b c \\
=\frac{c}{a(b+c)}+\frac{a}{b(a+c)}+\frac{b}{c(a+b)} \text {; } \\
S \geqslant \frac{b c}{a(b+c)} \cdot a b+\frac{a c}{b(a+c)} \cdot b c+\frac{a b}{c(a+b)} \cdot a c \\
=\frac{b}{a(b+c)}+\frac{c}{b(a+c)}+\frac{a}{c(a+b)} \\
\end{array}
$$

Adding the two inequalities, we get
$$
2 S \geqslant \frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c} \geqslant 3 \sqrt[3]{\frac{1}{a b c}}=3 \text {. Hence } S \geqslant \frac{3}{2} \text {. }
$$
informal_statement: Example 5 Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers, and satisfy $abc=1$. Try to prove: $\frac{1}{a^{3}(b+c)}+\frac{1}{b^{3}(a+b)}+\frac{1}{c^{3}(a+b)} \geqslant \frac{3}{2}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 5 Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers, and satisfy $abc=1$. Try to prove: $\frac{1}{a^{3}(b+c)}+\frac{1}{b^{3}(a+b)}+\frac{1}{c^{3}(a+b)} \geqslant \frac{3}{2}$. -/
theorem inequalities_120702 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a * b * c = 1) :
    3 / 2 ‚â§ 1 / (a ^ 3 * (b + c)) + 1 / (b ^ 3 * (a + b)) + 1 / (c ^ 3 * (a + b)) := by

soln_description:
Solution. Denote \(x=4(ab+bc+ca)\) and \(y=8abc\) then we obtain
\[a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=1-\frac{x}{2} ; \quad a^{2}b^{2}+b^{2}c^{2}+c^{2}a^{2}=\frac{x^{2}}{16}-\frac{y}{4}\]

We can rewrite the inequality to the form
\[\begin{aligned}
& 2 x \geq(4-2 x+8 y)\left(x^{2}-4 y\right) \\
\Leftrightarrow & x(x-1)^{2} \geq 4 y((x-1)(x+2)-4 y) \\
\Leftrightarrow & x(x-1)^{2}+16 y^{2} \geq 4 y(x-1)(x+2)
\end{aligned}\]

Obviously, \(x \leq \frac{4}{3}\). If \(x \leq 1\), we are done immediately. Otherwise, suppose that \(x \geq 1\). By the third degree-Schur inequality, it's easy to get \(8(x-1) \leq 9 y\). Considering \(x\) as a parameter in \(\left[1, \frac{4}{3}\right]\), we will prove that \(f(y) \geq 0\), where
\[f(y)=16 y^{2}-4 y(x-1)(x+2)+x(x-1)^{2}\]
informal_statement:
Example 8.2.7. Let \(a, b, c\) be non-negative real numbers with sum 1. Prove that
\[
\frac{a b + b c + c a}{a^{2} + b^{2} + c^{2} + 16 a b c} \geq 8\left(a^{2} b^{2} + b^{2} c^{2} + c^{2} a^{2}\right)
\]
(Pham Kim Hung, MYM)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 8.2.7. Let \(a, b, c\) be non-negative real numbers with sum 1. Prove that
\[
\frac{a b + b c + c a}{a^{2} + b^{2} + c^{2} + 16 a b c} \geq 8\left(a^{2} b^{2} + b^{2} c^{2} + c^{2} a^{2}\right)
\]
(Pham Kim Hung, MYM) -/
theorem inequalities_601227
    (a b c : ‚Ñù)
    (h‚ÇÄ : 0 ‚â§ a)
    (h‚ÇÅ : 0 ‚â§ b)
    (h‚ÇÇ : 0 ‚â§ c)
    (h‚ÇÉ : a + b + c = 1) :
    (a * b + b * c + c * a) / (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 + 16 * a * b * c) ‚â•
    8 * (a ^ 2 * b ^ 2 + b ^ 2 * c ^ 2 + c ^ 2 * a ^ 2) := by

soln_description:
$$
(\sin x+\cos x)^{2}=1+2 \sin x \cos x=\frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow \sin x \cos x=-\frac{1}{4} \text {, }
$$

So $\sin ^{3} x+\cos ^{3} x=(\sin x+\cos x)(1-\sin x \cos x)=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \cdot \frac{5}{4}=\frac{5 \sqrt{2}}{8}$.
informal_statement: 2. If $\sin x+\cos x=$ $\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$, then $\sin ^{3} x+\cos ^{3} x=$ $\qquad$
informal_proof:
We want to prove that if \( \sin x + \cos x = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \), then \( \sin^3 x + \cos^3 x = \frac{5\sqrt{2}}{8} \).

We begin by applying the sum of cubes algebraic identity, which states that for any real numbers \( a \) and \( b \), \( a^3 + b^3 = (a+b)(a^2 - ab + b^2) \).
Applying this identity to \( \sin^3 x + \cos^3 x \), we get:
\[
\sin^3 x + \cos^3 x = (\sin x + \cos x)(\sin^2 x - \sin x \cos x + \cos^2 x)
\]
Let's call this equation (1).

Now we can use the given hypothesis, \( \sin x + \cos x = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \), to substitute into equation (1):
\[
\sin^3 x + \cos^3 x = \left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)(\sin^2 x - \sin x \cos x + \cos^2 x)
\]
To proceed, we need to find the value of the term \( (\sin^2 x - \sin x \cos x + \cos^2 x) \). This requires determining the value of \( \sin x \cos x \).

We can find \( \sin x \cos x \) by squaring the given hypothesis:
\[
(\sin x + \cos x)^2 = \left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)^2
\]
Expanding the left side using the identity \( (a+b)^2 = a^2 + b^2 + 2ab \), we get:
\[
\sin^2 x + \cos^2 x + 2 \sin x \cos x = \left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)^2
\]
We know the fundamental trigonometric identity \( \sin^2 x + \cos^2 x = 1 \). Substituting this into the equation:
\[
1 + 2 \sin x \cos x = \left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)^2
\]
Now, let's calculate the right side:
\[
\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)^2 = \frac{(\sqrt{2})^2}{2^2} = \frac{2}{4} = \frac{1}{2}
\]
So, the equation becomes:
\[
1 + 2 \sin x \cos x = \frac{1}{2}
\]
Subtracting 1 from both sides:
\[
2 \sin x \cos x = \frac{1}{2} - 1 = -\frac{1}{2}
\]
Dividing by 2, we find:
\[
\sin x \cos x = -\frac{1}{4}
\]
Now we have the value for \( \sin x \cos x \). Let's use this to evaluate the remaining part of equation (1):
\[
\sin^2 x - \sin x \cos x + \cos^2 x
\]
We can rearrange this as:
\[
(\sin^2 x + \cos^2 x) - \sin x \cos x
\]
Substituting \( \sin^2 x + \cos^2 x = 1 \) and \( \sin x \cos x = -\frac{1}{4} \):
\[
1 - \left(-\frac{1}{4}\right) = 1 + \frac{1}{4} = \frac{5}{4}
\]
So, we have found that \( (\sin^2 x - \sin x \cos x + \cos^2 x) = \frac{5}{4} \).

Finally, we substitute this value back into our modified equation (1):
\[
\sin^3 x + \cos^3 x = \left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) \left(\frac{5}{4}\right)
\]
Performing the multiplication:
\[
\sin^3 x + \cos^3 x = \frac{\sqrt{2} \cdot 5}{2 \cdot 4} = \frac{5\sqrt{2}}{8}
\]
Thus, we have shown that if \( \sin x + \cos x = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \), then \( \sin^3 x + \cos^3 x = \frac{5\sqrt{2}}{8} \).

The final answer is \( \boxed{\frac{5\sqrt{2}}{8}} \).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. If $\sin x+\cos x=$ $\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$, then $\sin ^{3} x+\cos ^{3} x=$ $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_100746 (x : ‚Ñù) (h : Real.sin x + Real.cos x = Real.sqrt 2 / 2) :
    (Real.sin x)^3 + (Real.cos x)^3 = 5 * Real.sqrt 2 / 8 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_100746 (x : ‚Ñù) (h : Real.sin x + Real.cos x = Real.sqrt 2 / 2) :
    (Real.sin x)^3 + (Real.cos x)^3 = 5 * Real.sqrt 2 / 8 := by 
  have h1 : (Real.sin x)^3 + (Real.cos x)^3 = (Real.sin x + Real.cos x) * ((Real.sin x)^2 - Real.sin x * Real.cos x + (Real.cos x)^2) := by 
    ring
  rw [h1, h]
  have h2 : (Real.sin x)^2 + (Real.cos x)^2 = 1 := Real.sin_sq_add_cos_sq x
  have h3 : Real.sin x * Real.cos x = -1 / 4 := by 
    have h4 : (Real.sin x + Real.cos x)^2 = (Real.sqrt 2 / 2)^2 := by 
      rw [h]
    have h5 : (Real.sin x + Real.cos x)^2 = (Real.sin x)^2 + (Real.cos x)^2 + 2 * (Real.sin x * Real.cos x) := by 
      ring
    rw [h5] at h4 
    have h6 : (Real.sqrt 2 / 2 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2 = 1 / 2 := by 
      calc
        (Real.sqrt 2 / 2 : ‚Ñù) ^ 2 = (Real.sqrt 2 ^ 2) / 4 := by ring
        _ = (2) / 4 := by rw [Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ (2 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num)]
        _ = (1 : ‚Ñù) / 2 := by norm_num
    rw [h6] at h4 
    have h7 : (Real.sin x)^2 + (Real.cos x)^2 = 1 := h2 
    rw [h7] at h4 
    linarith 
  have h4 : (Real.sin x)^2 - Real.sin x * Real.cos x + (Real.cos x)^2 = 5 / 4 := by 
    have h5 : (Real.sin x)^2 + (Real.cos x)^2 = 1 := h2 
    have h6 : Real.sin x * Real.cos x = -1 / 4 := h3 
    linarith 
  rw [h4]
  have h7 : Real.sqrt 2 / 2 * (5 / 4 : ‚Ñù) = 5 * Real.sqrt 2 / 8 := by 
    ring 
  linarith [h7]

soln_description: Solution. For example, $\left(2018^{1010} \cdot 13 ; 2018^{1010} \cdot 43\right)$
informal_statement: 11.2. Prove that the equation $x^{2}+y^{2}=2018^{2021}$ is solvable in natural numbers.
informal_proof:
To prove that the equation \(x^{2}+y^{2}=2018^{2021}\) is solvable in natural numbers, we need to demonstrate the existence of at least one pair of natural numbers \((x, y)\) that satisfies this equation.

We propose the following specific values for \(x\) and \(y\):
Let \(x = 13 \cdot 2018^{1010}\)
Let \(y = 43 \cdot 2018^{1010}\)

Since \(13\), \(43\), \(2018\), and \(1010\) are all natural numbers, it follows that \(x\) and \(y\) constructed in this manner are also natural numbers.

Now, we substitute these proposed values of \(x\) and \(y\) into the given equation and verify if the equality holds:
\[
x^2 + y^2 = (13 \cdot 2018^{1010})^2 + (43 \cdot 2018^{1010})^2
\]
Using the property of exponents \((ab)^c = a^c b^c\), we can expand each term:
\[
(13 \cdot 2018^{1010})^2 = 13^2 \cdot (2018^{1010})^2 = 169 \cdot 2018^{2020}
\]
and
\[
(43 \cdot 2018^{1010})^2 = 43^2 \cdot (2018^{1010})^2 = 1849 \cdot 2018^{2020}
\]
Now, sum these two results:
\[
x^2 + y^2 = 169 \cdot 2018^{2020} + 1849 \cdot 2018^{2020}
\]
We can factor out the common term \(2018^{2020}\):
\[
x^2 + y^2 = (169 + 1849) \cdot 2018^{2020}
\]
Perform the addition inside the parentheses:
\[
169 + 1849 = 2018
\]
Substituting this sum back into the expression:
\[
x^2 + y^2 = 2018 \cdot 2018^{2020}
\]
Finally, using the property of exponents \(a^m \cdot a^n = a^{m+n}\), we can simplify the right side:
\[
x^2 + y^2 = 2018^{1+2020} = 2018^{2021}
\]
This matches the right-hand side of the original equation.

Since we have found specific natural numbers \(x = 13 \cdot 2018^{1010}\) and \(y = 43 \cdot 2018^{1010}\) that satisfy the equation, we have proven its solvability in natural numbers.

Therefore, such natural numbers \(x\) and \(y\) exist.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 11.2. Prove that the equation $x^{2}+y^{2}=2018^{2021}$ is solvable in natural numbers. -/
theorem number_theory_107771 : ‚àÉ x y : ‚Ñï, x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 = 2018 ^ 2021 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_107771 : ‚àÉ x y : ‚Ñï, x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 = 2018 ^ 2021 := by 
  use 13 * 2018 ^ 1010, 43 * 2018 ^ 1010
  norm_num

soln_description:
1. **Define the Fibonacci sequence and the given conditions:**
   The Fibonacci sequence is defined as:
   \[
   f_1 = f_2 = 1, \quad f_{n+2} = f_{n+1} + f_n \quad (n \in \mathbb{N})
   \]
   Suppose \( a \) and \( b \) are positive integers such that:
   \[
   \frac{f_n}{f_{n-1}} < \frac{a}{b} < \frac{f_{n+1}}{f_n}
   \]

2. **Generalize the problem using mediants:**
   Let us call \(\dfrac{a+c}{b+d}\) the mediant of the fractions \(\dfrac{a}{b}\) and \(\dfrac{c}{d}\). If \(|ad - bc| = 1\), then for every fraction \(\dfrac{p}{q}\) that lies between them, the denominator \(q\) is greater than or equal to \(b + d\).

3. **Consider the specific case for Fibonacci fractions:**
   We need to show that for any fraction \(\dfrac{p}{q}\) between \(\dfrac{f_n}{f_{n-1}}\) and \(\dfrac{f_{n+1}}{f_n}\), the denominator \(q\) satisfies \(q \geq f_{n+1}\).

4. **Use the property of mediants:**
   Take \(\dfrac{a}{b} < \dfrac{p}{q} < \dfrac{c}{d}\) and assume \(ad - bc = -1\). Then:
   \[
   \dfrac{p}{q} - \dfrac{a}{b} \geq \dfrac{1}{bq} \quad \text{and} \quad \dfrac{c}{d} - \dfrac{p}{q} \geq \dfrac{1}{dq}
   \]
   Adding these inequalities:
   \[
   \dfrac{c}{d} - \dfrac{a}{b} \geq \dfrac{1}{bq} + \dfrac{1}{dq}
   \]

5. **Simplify the inequality:**
   Since \(\dfrac{c}{d} - \dfrac{a}{b} = \dfrac{1}{bd}\), we have:
   \[
   \dfrac{1}{bd} \geq \dfrac{b + d}{bdq}
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   \dfrac{1}{bd} \geq \dfrac{b + d}{bdq} \implies q \geq b + d
   \]

6. **Apply the result to the Fibonacci sequence:**
   In the case of the Fibonacci sequence, we have:
   \[
   \left| f_n^2 - f_{n-1} f_{n+1} \right| = 1
   \]
   Therefore, for any fraction \(\dfrac{p}{q}\) between \(\dfrac{f_n}{f_{n-1}}\) and \(\dfrac{f_{n+1}}{f_n}\), we have:
   \[
   q \geq f_n + f_{n-1} = f_{n+1}
   \]

Conclusion:
\[
\boxed{b \geq f_{n+1}}
\]
informal_statement: The Fibonacci sequence is defined as $f_1=f_2=1$, $f_{n+2}=f_{n+1}+f_n$ ($n\in\mathbb{N}$). Suppose that $a$ and $b$ are positive integers such that $\frac ab$ lies between the two fractions $\frac{f_n}{f_{n-1}}$ and $\frac{f_{n+1}}{f_{n}}$. Show that $b\ge f_{n+1}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The Fibonacci sequence is defined as $f_1=f_2=1$, $f_{n+2}=f_{n+1}+f_n$ ($n\in\mathbb{N}$). Suppose that $a$ and $b$ are positive integers such that $\frac ab$ lies between the two fractions $\frac{f_n}{f_{n-1}}$ and $\frac{f_{n+1}}{f_{n}}$. Show that $b\ge f_{n+1}$. -/
theorem number_theory_46407 {f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñö} (hf : ‚àÄ n, f (n + 2) = f (n + 1) + f n)
    (hf1 : f 1 = 1) (hf2 : f 2 = 1) (a b : ‚Ñ§) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h : f n / f (n - 1) < a / b ‚àß a / b < f (n + 1) / f n) :
    b ‚â• f (n + 1) := by

soln_description:
Let $\frac{b_{i}}{a_{i}}=k_{i} \geqslant 1, i=1,2, \cdots, n, \frac{B}{A}=K$, then $k_{1} k_{2} \cdots k_{n} \leqslant K$.
Since $\frac{b_{i}+1}{a_{i}+1}=\frac{k_{i} a_{i}+1}{a_{i}+1}=\frac{k_{i} a_{i}+k_{i}-\left(k_{i}-1\right)}{a_{i}+1}=k_{i}-\frac{k_{i}-1}{a_{i}+1} \leqslant k_{i}-\frac{k_{i}-1}{A+1}$
$=\frac{k_{i} A+k_{i}-\left(k_{i}-1\right)}{A+1}=\frac{k_{i} A+1}{A+1}, \frac{B+1}{A+1}=\frac{K A+1}{A+1} \geqslant \frac{k_{1} k_{2} \cdots k_{n} A+1}{A+1}$,
it suffices to prove $\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{k_{i} A+1}{A+1} \leqslant \frac{k_{1} k_{2} \cdots k_{n} A+1}{A+1}$.
When $n=1$, $\frac{k_{1} A+1}{A+1}=\frac{k_{1} A+1}{A+1}$, the proposition is obviously true;
When $n=2$, $\frac{k_{1} A+1}{A+1} \cdot \frac{k_{2} A+1}{A+1} \leqslant \frac{k_{1} k_{2} A+1}{A+1}$
$\Leftrightarrow\left(k_{1} A+1\right)\left(k_{2} A+1\right) \leqslant\left(k_{1} k_{2} A+1\right)(A+1) \Leftrightarrow k_{1} A+k_{2} A \leqslant k_{1} k_{2} A+A$
$\Leftrightarrow k_{1} k_{2}+1-k_{1}-k_{2} \geqslant 0 \Leftrightarrow\left(k_{1}-1\right)\left(k_{2}-1\right) \geqslant 0$, the proposition is obviously true;
Assume the proposition holds for a positive integer $n(n \geqslant 2)$, i.e., $\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{k_{i} A+1}{A+1} \leqslant \frac{k_{1} k_{2} \cdots k_{n} A+1}{A+1}$,
then for $n+1$, we have $\prod_{i=1}^{n+1} \frac{k_{i} A+1}{A+1}=\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{k_{i} A+1}{A+1} \cdot \frac{k_{n+1} A+1}{A+1}$
$\leqslant \frac{k_{1} k_{2} \cdots k_{n} A+1}{A+1} \cdot \frac{k_{n+1} A+1}{A+1}$, similarly for $n=2$, we have
$\frac{k_{1} k_{2} \cdots k_{n} A+1}{A+1} \cdot \frac{k_{n+1} A+1}{A+1} \leqslant \frac{k_{1} k_{2} \cdots k_{n} k_{n+1} A+1}{A+1}$
$\Leftrightarrow\left(k_{1} k_{2} \cdots k_{n}-1\right)\left(k_{n+1}-1\right) \geqslant 0$, thus the proposition holds for the positive integer $n+1$.
By the principle of mathematical induction, the proposition holds for all positive integers. Therefore, the original inequality holds.
informal_statement:
1. Let $n$ be a positive integer, $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \cdots, b_{n} ; A, B$ be positive real numbers, satisfying $a_{i} \leqslant b_{i}, a_{i} \leqslant A, i=1,2, \cdots, n$, and $\frac{b_{1} b_{2} \cdots b_{n}}{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \leqslant \frac{B}{A}$.
Prove: $\frac{\left(b_{1}+1\right)\left(b_{2}+1\right) \cdots\left(b_{n}+1\right)}{\left(a_{1}+1\right)\left(a_{2}+1\right) \cdots\left(a_{n}+1\right)} \leqslant \frac{B+1}{A+1}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 1. Let $n$ be a positive integer, $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n} ; b_{1}, b_{2}, \cdots, b_{n} ; A, B$ be positive real numbers, satisfying $a_{i} \leqslant b_{i}, a_{i} \leqslant A, i=1,2, \cdots, n$, and $\frac{b_{1} b_{2} \cdots b_{n}}{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}} \leqslant \frac{B}{A}$.
Prove: $\frac{\left(b_{1}+1\right)\left(b_{2}+1\right) \cdots\left(b_{n}+1\right)}{\left(a_{1}+1\right)\left(a_{2}+1\right) \cdots\left(a_{n}+1\right)} \leqslant \frac{B+1}{A+1}$. -/
theorem inequalities_290214 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) (a b : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (A B : ‚Ñù) (ha : ‚àÄ i, 0 < a i) (hb : ‚àÄ i, 0 < b i) (hA : 0 < A) (hB : 0 < B)
    (h : ‚àÄ i, a i ‚â§ b i ‚àß a i ‚â§ A) (h' : ‚àè i, b i / a i ‚â§ B / A) :
    ‚àè i, (b i + 1) / (a i + 1) ‚â§ (B + 1) / (A + 1) := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{aligned}
S & =r_{1}^{2}+r_{2}^{2}+r_{3}^{2}+r_{4}^{2} \\
& =\left(r_{1}+r_{2}+r_{3}+r_{4}\right)^{2}-2\left(r_{1} r_{2}+r_{1} r_{3}+r_{1} r_{4}+r_{2} r_{3}+r_{2} r_{4}+r_{3} r_{4}\right) \\
& =\left(-\frac{1-10 / t)}{1 / t}\right)^{2}-2 \frac{-2}{1 / t} \\
& =t^{2}-16 t+100
\end{aligned}
$$

A study of this quadratic shows that the minimum value of $|S|$ is 36 and is achieved at $t=8$.
informal_statement:
For all $t>0$, consider the sum $S=r_{1}^{2}+r_{2}^{2}+r_{3}^{2}+r_{4}^{2}$, where $r_{1}, r_{2}, r_{3}, r_{4}$ are the roots of the polynomial

$$
P_{t}[X]=\frac{1}{t} X^{4}+\left(1-\frac{10}{t}\right) X^{3}-2 X^{2}+\sqrt[3]{2 t} X+\arctan (t)
$$

What is the minimum value of $|S|$ and for which $t$ is it achieved?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Polynomial

/- For all $t>0$, consider the sum $S=r_{1}^{2}+r_{2}^{2}+r_{3}^{2}+r_{4}^{2}$, where $r_{1}, r_{2}, r_{3}, r_{4}$ are the roots of the polynomial

$$
P_{t}[X]=\frac{1}{t} X^{4}+\left(1-\frac{10}{t}\right) X^{3}-2 X^{2}+\sqrt[3]{2 t} X+\arctan (t)
$$

What is the minimum value of $|S|$ and for which $t$ is it achieved? -/
theorem algebra_125056 {P : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
    (hP : P = fun t x => t ^ (-1 : ‚Ñ§) * x ^ 4 + (1 - 10 / t) * x ^ 3 - 2 * x ^ 2 + (2 * t) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) * x + arctan t)
    (r : ‚Ñù ‚Üí Fin 4 ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hr : ‚àÄ t, r t = fun i => P t (r t i))
    (S : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hS : ‚àÄ t, S t = ‚àë i, (r t i) ^ 2) :
    IsLeast {x | ‚àÉ t, x = |S t|} 36 := by

soln_description: As $g \circ f$ is bijective, $g$ is surjective and $f$ is injective. Moreover, if $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $f(x)^{2}=f(g(f(x)))=f\left(x^{3}\right)$ and thus $f\left(x^{3}\right)=f(x)^{2}$. Therefore, if $x \in\{-1,0,1\}$, we have $f(x)=f\left(x^{3}\right)=f(x)^{2}$, hence $f(x)=0$ or 1. But this contradicts the injectivity of $f$.
informal_statement:
Do there exist two functions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ and $g: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$ :

$$
f(g(x))=x^{2} \text { and } g(f(x))=x^{3}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Do there exist two functions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ and $g: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$ :

$$
f(g(x))=x^{2} \text { and } g(f(x))=x^{3}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_137235 : ‚àÉ (f g : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù), ‚àÄ x, f (g x) = x ^ 2 ‚àß g (f x) = x ^ 3 := by

informal_statement:
(2008 Australian $AMC$ C Level (Grades 7-8) Q26)

There is a two-digit number $ab$ and its reverse $ba$ are both prime numbers. For example, $13$ and $31$ are both prime numbers. What is the maximum possible sum of $ab$ and $ba$ that satisfies the above condition?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (2008 Australian $AMC$ C Level (Grades 7-8) Q26)

There is a two-digit number $ab$ and its reverse $ba$ are both prime numbers. For example, $13$ and $31$ are both prime numbers. What is the maximum possible sum of $ab$ and $ba$ that satisfies the above condition? -/
theorem number_theory_7777 :
    IsGreatest {x | ‚àÉ a b : ‚Ñï, a ‚â† 0 ‚àß b ‚â† 0 ‚àß Nat.Prime (10 * a + b) ‚àß Nat.Prime (10 * b + a) ‚àß x = 10 * a + b + 10 * b + a} 176 := by

informal_statement: Determine the smallest multiple of $2016$ such that the sum of its digits equals $2016$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine the smallest multiple of $2016$ such that the sum of its digits equals $2016$. -/
theorem number_theory_4875 (n : ‚Ñï) (h1 : IsLeast {m | 2016 ‚à£ m ‚àß (Nat.digits 10 m).sum = 2016} n) : n = 2016 * (10^896 - 1) / (10^4 - 1) := by

soln_description:
SOLUTION. We will show that the given 35-element set $M$ contains at least 18 fair numbers, which is more than the number of numbers in it that are not fair.

It suffices to prove that every positive divisor of the number $2^{1010} \cdot 3^{2} \cdot 5^{1010}$ is a fair number. From this, it follows that all 18 numbers in the subset

$$
S=\{1,2,3,4,5,6,8,9,10,12,15,16,18,20,24,25,30,32\}
$$

of set $M$ are fair. The idea of proving the fairness of each $k$ with the property $k \mid 2^{1010} \cdot 3^{2} \cdot 5^{1010}$ will be presented immediately after we divide all palindromes of lengths 2021 and 2022 into suitable groups, introduce useful notation for them, and add insights about divisibility that will clarify the subsequent proof.

Consider any 1010-digit number $n$ and denote by $A_{n}$ (resp. $B_{n}$) the set of 2021-digit (resp. 2022-digit) palindromes whose first 1010 digits are given by $n$. This way, we have divided all the palindromes under consideration into groups $A_{n}$ and $B_{n}$, where the numbers in the same group not only share the first but also the last 1010 digits. Therefore, to specify a number from $A_{n}$, resp. $B_{n}$, it suffices to determine its middle digit, resp. its middle two-digit number, and this can be done by any choice from the set

$$
J=\{0,1,2, \ldots, 9\}, \quad \text { resp. } \quad D=\{00,11,22,33,44,55,66,77,88,99\}
$$

Thus, there are exactly 10 numbers in $A_{n}$ and $B_{n}$, and we will denote them by the notations $[n, j]$, resp. $[n, d]$, where $j \in J$ and $d \in D$. The fact that all palindromes $[n, j]$ and $[n, d]$ with a given $n$ end with the 1010-digit number obtained by reading the number $n$ from right to left will have two consequences for us: The numbers $[n, j]$ and $[n, d]$ give the same remainders as the numbers $2 n+j$, resp. $2 n+d$ (since $10^{i} \equiv 1 \quad(\bmod 9)$ for every integer $i \geqq 0$), and their divisibility by $2^{a}$ and $5^{a}$, where $a \in\langle 1,1010\rangle$ is an integer, is determined by the first $a$ digits of the given $n$.

We are now ready to prove the fairness of every number $k=2^{a} \cdot 3^{b} \cdot 5^{c}$, where $a, c \in\langle 0,1010\rangle$ and $b \in\langle 0,2\rangle$ are (and everywhere else) integers. To do this, we will show that the number of multiples of such a $k$ is the same in both sets $A_{n}$ and $B_{n}$, regardless of the permissible $n$. By summing these counts over all possible 1010-digit numbers $n$, we will then obtain the desired conclusion.

The statement about the same number of multiples of a given $k$ in the sets $A_{n}$ and $B_{n}$ with a given (and everywhere else fixed) number $n$ is obvious in the case $k=1$ (both counts are 10). For other specified $k$, we will distinguish 4 cases, in which we will use the insights about divisibility (from the third paragraph of the solution) without reference.

a) Case $k=2^{a} 5^{c}$, where $\max (a, c) \in\langle 1,1010\rangle$. The divisibility of the numbers $[n, j]$ and $[n, d]$ by such a number $k$ is determined by the first $\max (a, c)$ digits of the number $n$, so the statement holds - either all numbers in $A_{n}$ and $B_{n}$ (ten each) are multiples of $k$, or none of the numbers in $A_{n}$ or $B_{n}$ are.

b) Case $k=3^{2}=9$. The numbers $[n, j]$ and $[n, d]$ give the same remainder when divided by nine as the numbers $2 n+j$, resp. $2 n+d$. The remainders of the numbers $d \in D$ when divided by nine are, according to the notation of $D$ in a), in order $0,2,4,6,8,1,3,5,7,0$, i.e., each remainder except zero occurs once and zero occurs twice. Therefore, if $n$ is a multiple of nine, the sets $A_{n}, B_{n}$ contain two multiples of nine each, otherwise one multiple of nine each.

c) Case $k=3^{1}$. The numbers $[n, j]$ and $[n, d]$ can be replaced modulo 3 by the numbers $2 n+j$, resp. $2 n+d$. When divided by three, the numbers $j \in J$ give remainders in order $0,1,2,0,1,2,0,1,2,0$ and the two-digit numbers $d \in D$ give remainders $0,2,1,0,2,1,0,2,1,0$. Therefore, if $n$ is a multiple of three, both sets $A_{n}, B_{n}$ contain four multiples of three each, otherwise three multiples of three each.

d) Case $k=2^{a} \cdot 3^{b} \cdot 5^{c}$, where $\max (a, c) \in\langle 1,1010\rangle$ and $b \in\langle 1,2\rangle$. Consider first the number $k^{\prime}=2^{a} 5^{c}$. From the proof of case a) it follows that either all numbers in $A_{n}$ and $B_{n}$ are multiples of $k^{\prime}$, or none of them are. If the first possibility occurs, from the result of the case $k=3^{b}$ it follows that both sets $A_{n}$ and $B_{n}$ contain the same number of multiples of $3^{b}$, and thus also of the number $3^{b} \cdot k^{\prime}=k$. If the second possibility occurs, neither of the sets $A_{n}$, $B_{n}$ contains a multiple of $k^{\prime}$, and thus no multiple of $k$.

This completes the entire solution.

NOTE. Using a computer, it can be verified that the given set $M$ contains exactly 18 fair numbers, which we have thus determined in full.
informal_statement:
2. Let's say a positive integer $k$ is fair if the number of 2021-digit palindromes that are multiples of $k$ is the same as the number of 2022-digit palindromes that are multiples of $k$. Does the set $M=\{1,2, \ldots, 35\}$ contain more numbers that are fair or more numbers that are not fair?

(A palindrome is a natural number whose decimal representation reads the same from left to right as from right to left.)

(David Hru≈°ka, Josef Tkadlec)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def isFair (k : ‚Ñï) : Prop :=
  {n | (Nat.digits 10 n).length = 2021 ‚àß Nat.digits 10 n = List.reverse (Nat.digits 10 n) ‚àß k ‚à£ n}.ncard =
    {n | (Nat.digits 10 n).length = 2022 ‚àß Nat.digits 10 n = List.reverse (Nat.digits 10 n) ‚àß k ‚à£ n}.ncard

/- 2. Let's say a positive integer $k$ is fair if the number of 2021-digit palindromes that are multiples of $k$ is the same as the number of 2022-digit palindromes that are multiples of $k$. Does the set $M=\{1,2, \ldots, 35\}$ contain more numbers that are fair or more numbers that are not fair?

(A palindrome is a natural number whose decimal representation reads the same from left to right as from right to left.)

(David Hru≈°ka, Josef Tkadlec) -/
theorem number_theory_267624 :
    {k | k ‚àà Finset.Icc 1 35 ‚àß isFair k}.ncard = 18 := by

informal_statement:
Prove the inequality
\[(-a+b+c)^2(a-b+c)^2(a+b-c)^2 \geq (-a^2+b^2+c^2)(a^2-b^2+c^2)(a^2+b^2-c^2)\]
for all real numbers $a, b, c.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove the inequality
\[(-a+b+c)^2(a-b+c)^2(a+b-c)^2 \geq (-a^2+b^2+c^2)(a^2-b^2+c^2)(a^2+b^2-c^2)\]
for all real numbers $a, b, c.$ -/
theorem inequalities_26746 (a b c : ‚Ñù) :
    (-a + b + c)^2 * (a - b + c)^2 * (a + b - c)^2 ‚â•
    (-a^2 + b^2 + c^2) * (a^2 - b^2 + c^2) * (a^2 + b^2 - c^2) := by

soln_description:
Consider the function
$$
f(x)=\frac{1}{x-1}+\frac{2}{x-2}+\cdots+\frac{200}{x-200}-10 \text {. }
$$

For any real number $x$.

For any $k$ in the set $\{1,2, \cdots, 200\}$, when $x \rightarrow k-0$, $f(x) \rightarrow-\infty$, and when $x \rightarrow k+0$, $f(x) \rightarrow+\infty$. Also, when $x \rightarrow+\infty$, $x \rightarrow-10$. Therefore, the equation $f(x)=0$ has one solution in each of the intervals
$$
(1,2),(2,3), \cdots,(199,200),(200,+\infty).
$$

Let these 200 solutions be denoted as $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{200}$.
Construct the polynomial
$$
P(x)=(x-1)(x-2) \cdots(x-200) f(x) \text {. }
$$

Since $P(x)$ is a 200th-degree polynomial, the equation $P(x)=0$ has at most 200 distinct roots. Clearly, each $x_{i}$ that satisfies $f(x)=0$ is also a root of $P(x)=0$.

Therefore, $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{200}$ are all the roots of $P(x)=0$.

This indicates that each $x_{k}$ is the unique root in its respective interval $(k, k+1)$ $(k=1,2, \cdots, 199)$ and $(200,+\infty)$.
Thus, the solution set of the inequality $f(x)>0$ is
$$
E=\left(1, x_{1}\right) \cup\left(2, x_{2}\right) \cup \cdots \cup\left(200, x_{200}\right) \text {. }
$$

Hence, the total sum of the lengths of all intervals is
$$
\begin{aligned}
S & =\left(x_{1}-1\right)+\left(x_{2}-2\right)+\cdots+\left(x_{200}-200\right) \\
& =\left(x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{200}\right)-(1+2+\cdots+200) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{200} x_{i}-10 \times 2010 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Notice that
$$
P(x)=\left[\prod_{i=1}^{200}(x-i)\right]\left(\sum_{i=1}^{200} \frac{i}{x-i}-10\right),
$$

If we expand $P(x)$, the coefficient of the highest degree term is -10.
Thus, the coefficient of $x^{199}$ in $P(x)$ is
$$
(10+1) \sum_{k=1}^{200} k=11 \times 20100 \text {. }
$$

Therefore, $\sum_{i=1}^{200} x_{i}=11 \times 2010$.
From equation (1), we get
$$
S=\sum_{i=1}^{200} x_{i}-10 \times 2010=2010 .
$$
informal_statement:
II. (40 points) Prove: The set $E$ of real numbers $x$ that satisfy the inequality
$$
\frac{1}{x-1}+\frac{2}{x-2}+\cdots+\frac{200}{x-200}>10
$$

can be expressed as the union of some mutually disjoint open intervals. Find the total length of these intervals.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- II. (40 points) Prove: The set $E$ of real numbers $x$ that satisfy the inequality
$$
\frac{1}{x-1}+\frac{2}{x-2}+\cdots+\frac{200}{x-200}>10
$$

can be expressed as the union of some mutually disjoint open intervals. Find the total length of these intervals. -/
theorem inequalities_300967 :
  (MeasureTheory.volume {x : ‚Ñù | ‚àë i : Fin 200, (i + 1) / (x - (i + 1)) > 10}).toReal =
  100 := by

soln_description:
Solution: If $N=1$, then the sum is just $1 /\left(a_{1}+1\right)=1 / 31$. It is easy to see recursively (that is using induction) that $a_{j}>1$ for all $j$. We observe that

$$
\begin{gathered}
a_{j+1}-a_{j}=\frac{a_{j}^{2}+1}{2}-a_{j}=\frac{\left(a_{j}-1\right)^{2}}{2} \\
a_{j+1}-1=\frac{a_{j}^{2}+1}{2}-1=\frac{a_{j}^{2}-1}{2}=\frac{\left(a_{j}-1\right)\left(a_{j}+1\right)}{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{1}{a_{j}+1}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{a_{j}-1}{a_{j+1}-1}\right)
$$

for all $j \geq 1$. Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{1}{a_{j}+1}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{a_{j}-1}{a_{j+1}-1}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\left(a_{j}-1\right)^{2}}{\left(a_{j+1}-1\right)\left(a_{j}-1\right)} \\
&=\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{a_{j+1}-a_{j}}{\left(a_{j+1}-1\right)\left(a_{j}-1\right)} \\
&=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\frac{1}{a_{j}-1}-\frac{1}{a_{j+1}-1}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{a_{1}-1}-\frac{1}{a_{N+1}-1}<\frac{1}{a_{1}-1}=1 \\
&-0
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement:
6. Define a sequence $\left\langle a_{n}\right\rangle_{n \geq 1}$ of real numbers by

$$
a_{1}=2, \quad a_{n+1}=\frac{a_{n}^{2}+1}{2}, \text { for } n \geq 1
$$

Prove that

$$
\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{1}{a_{j}+1}<1
$$

for every natural number $N$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open scoped BigOperators

/- 
6. Define a sequence $\left\langle a_{n}\right\rangle_{n \geq 1}$ of real numbers by

$$
a_{1}=2, \quad a_{n+1}=\frac{a_{n}^{2}+1}{2}, \text { for } n \geq 1
$$

Prove that

$$
\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{1}{a_{j}+1}<1
$$

for every natural number $N$.
 -/
theorem inequalities_121949
  (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (h‚ÇÄ : a 1 = 2)
  (h‚ÇÅ : ‚àÄ n ‚â• 1, a (n + 1) = ((a n)^2 + 1) / 2) :
  ‚àÄ N, ‚àë j in Finset.Icc 1 N, 1 / (a j + 1) < 1 :=
